text:
I'm thinking of trying either a late 30kwh gen1 or early gen2 leaf on my parents. They are getting on and increasingly use their small car for very short trips, less than a mile and a half each way. They used to walk most of the time but aren't so capable of that now. The small petrol car they have doesn't even fully warm up, sometimes for several trips in a row and as a result is causing the warning light to come on. They never take it more than about 30 miles from home either and rarely that far, so an 80 mile range and only home charging is no problem. An electric motor doesn't care how short your journeys are. 
The only problem is my Dad won't have one because it wouldn't be capable of a theoretical journey that he hasn't been on in the last 15 years and never will go on anyway, but he will have a petrol car even though it is likely to mean some huge bills in the future when the catalytic converter dies due to the useage.

text:
A more balanced review of a fairly modern car regardless of the power source.

A vehicle with a reliable 150 miles even in winter is more than sufficient for 95% of drivers.  The average car use per day is around 20 miles in the UK and most people do not go on journeys of over 100 miles with any sort of regularity.

We have an EV.  It's not a Nissan though it has similar battery capacity and motor power but will do more real miles than the Nissan does.   Our everyday need is low but round trips with an oldie to the hospital can result in 80 plus mile days.

We now have the ability to charge on cheap juice overnight even though we live in a Victorian terrace.  Local authorities are slowly but surely making this happen.

I love cars and my all time favourite is the Ford Anglia 123E Super with the 1200cc engine.  We had a 1967 vintage version and I loved everything about that car.   To be brutally honest though in the modern world a modern car is so much safer and more practical.

text:
Chademo is an actual standard whereas CCS has variations between manufacturers. Chademo is also designed with V2G in mind and V2G/V2H functionality was mandated for Japanese manufactured EVs in the wake of Fukushima as is presents the potential for EVs to provide grid resilience by acting en-masse as a utility scale grid storage facility.

We're onto our second Leaf (2012 24kWh, 2016 30kWh) and use of public charging is virtually nil for us. The upgrade was actually done last year with V2G very much in mind as we have solar and I'm hesitant to spend money on a static battery when a Leaf can do the job plus provide mobility.

Some very interesting info to be had in Robert Llewellyn's interview of David Slutzky of Fermata Energy on V2G's potential in electricity supply resilience and gaining income from your Leaf by way of their bidirectional charging functionality. Worth noting also that EV manufacturers are reacting to V2G demand and are now increasingly incorporating this in their vehicles, but the humble Leaf has had this almost from its debut.
author: @HarmLessSolutionsNZ

text: As far as cold weather goes ... the 2019 LEAF we bought two months ago has just been through a week of sub-minus-30 weather. (I live in Saskatchewan, because I am insane.) Never needs a boost, the cabin heats up in five minutes compared to 20-30 for the old Civic. The range isn't great even with the 62kWh battery, probably 150km in that bitter cold, but we're not regular highway drivers so it's just fine - and that's a worst case range, worse than worst-case for you Brits. Plug it into the side of the house at night, it's charged in the morning and you really don't need more than that. Best winter city driving car I've ever owned. I kinda like the "old-fashioned" interior with buttons for most things rather than having to navigate touch screen menus, too.

author: @Boating_David

text:
I've had a 2014 Leaf (24kWh) since 2019 and it was the most expensive second hand car I've ever bought (¬£7,500). But 4¬Ω years later it's paid for its purchase price in fuel savings alone compared to the 2005 Honda Civic it replaced. In October we had a V2H (Vehicle to Home) charger fitted and now I can charge it on cheap overnight electricity and use it as a battery to power my house (and soak up free power from my solar panels). For our family it's the gift that keeps on giving.

It's a great daily driver, like you said it's not exciting but it's very competent and it only costs us 2.3p/mile if we charge at home (we get a lot of free solar miles in the Summer too).

The bump in the middle of the rear floor is where the high voltage emergency disconnect lives, in the event of an accident the emergency services can pop it open and remove a plug to isolate the battery. With regard to Chademo, we're just beginning to see CCS to Chademo adapters as commercial products (>¬£800) so there will be some scope to keep using Chademo vehicles in the future.

text:
EVs are a technology going nowhere, in my opinion. 
The charging hassles are one of many problems. I see batteries as the cursing factor, with many aspects. Unless battery technology makes massive advances in the near future, EVs are a big failure. Winter, heating the car electrically is a disaster especially if you get stuck in any way. The tendency for batteries to burst into flame must be cured, at minimum some way of predicting the risk. Power storage is far to small. The batteries require relatively large amounts of rare earth minerals, these will be harder and harder to find, so a way of making batteries that store more energy without the minerals, a huge technology jump..
Talking Heads got it right "Road to nowhere"

text: I had a Leaf for two years. After 8000 miles its range was 35 miles in winter at night (- heater, lights, wipers etc). It needed a new ¬£5,000 battery. Factor that into your running costs - ¬£2500 per annum for batteries. The dealer said the 5 year warranty is void because I plugged it in to recharge it when it was already 80% full. Apparently the same applies if you let the battery go below 20%. In which case the useable range is actually 60% of its real range, which in turn is probably 85% of the manufacturer's claimed range. I have solar panels at home so of course when the sun shone on them I plugged it in. You would, wouldn't you? The dealer never told me not to plug it in if it was already 80% full, and why did the stupid computer on board allow this? That's the last time I have an EV.

text: The Leaf is the defacto example of a car that does have quite a bit of degradation, due to lack of proper battery management. Buying a 2nd hand Leaf requires a proper check of the battery. text: Interesting review. I bought a new Mercedes 220d 3 years ago, it does 60 to 70mpg day to day and I only need to fill it up once a month, a full tank gives a 900 mile range. It‚Äôs a lovely car and very convenient and cost effective to run. Recently I‚Äôve been looking at a Polestar on a scheme through my work. With a wall box I could keep it charged at home no problems with fuel costs being a little lower than the diesel Mercedes. What puts me off is the charging network away from home. Last year we did a road trip to Scotland in a PHEV car. We couldn‚Äôt find anywhere to charge the battery. Domestic supplies tripped out on the 3 pin plug, service area chargers were all in use, we found a bank of empty chargers but you needed an app to use them and there was no mobile internet to download the app‚Ä¶..Luckily we had the option of just running on petrol so did that instead.

text: The comments are hilarious Pro vs anti EV. Calm down people. There‚Äôs a place for both EVs and ICE and I think that‚Äôs the issue, at the moment with the current battery technology, EVs cannot replace ICE  for long journeys but for the cities they are perfect. Now the problem is EVs are getting bigger and bigger requiring bigger battery packs and you‚Äôd could argue that‚Äôs not an efficient use of resources. Small and light would be the way to go for use in cities. At the moment, it seems that plug in hybrids would be the best of both worlds, smaller battery packs with a range of 50 or so KM with the ability to hold the charge for city use. That range would suit most people‚Äôs daily driving and you have the ICE for longer trips then there‚Äôs no need for 90kwh of expensive and heavy batteries - a better use of resources cheaper and the ability to get more of them on the road.

text:
so much politics, so little time... I don't get it. Nobody seems to connect the dots.
I fervently believe in global warming and I like the idea of electric cars (I drive a dual fuel car and rely on LPG which is more environmentally friendly but the British government, after allowing grants for vehicle conversion subsequently forgot about LPG and so the associated fuel stations are all going‚Ä¶ except in Europe where people think differently). 
It‚Äôs an uncoordinated mess.
 There is no way that the infrastructure to support mass EV conversion is going to happen without huge (unforeseen!) issues . The figures don't add up and even if they did there are one or two (or twelve) issues left unaddressed:
The harvesting of the required rare earths from the bottom of the sea for battery manufacture and the environmental impact is just one issue left unfaced. 
The emerging danger of electric vehicle fires is another. 
Lots of people don't live in houses suitable for EV cars. Great if you have your own drive. Not so much if you don‚Äôt.
I could go on‚Ä¶
Everything connects, and until someone addresses the associated problems we will be forever stuck in an "oops, I never thought of that'' moment. Something we,  the British people seem, historically,  inordinately good at..

text: I looked up the kerb weights of various electric cars.  The Leaf, at around 1.7 tonnes, is, believe it or not, one of the lightest electric vehicles there is, although it's only around the same size as a Ford Fiesta.   I have a Ford C Max Grand 1.6 diesel which weighs less than a Nissan Leaf.  Many bigger electric cars weigh in at well north of 2 tonnes.  As a question to Ian, what is the point of the latest ad for a car (I can't remember which company it is, it might be Toyota) which burns petrol and then converts it to electric to drive the vehicle?  Am I missing something here?  It's like burning gas to generate electricity and then having a 100% electric cooker when you could have a gas one, or a dual fuel...

text:
I'm surprised at how far behind Nissan are with the Leaf in the EV world. As you alluded to, their focus now is on the Aria. It's a shame that so many manufacturers seem intent on releasing SUV after SUV which is why I've not gone for one until fairly recently. I love the idea of EV and have just ordered my first, a BMW i4 eDrive 40 M Sport Pro which I'm eagerly awaiting. Not very HubNut, but happy to lend it for a test drive if you ever feel the need (I'm in Wales too).

I don't get the hatred towards EV. Like you've also alluded to in other videos, it's nice to have a variety in the fleet. I like all sorts of cars regardless of propulsion. I have my V8 in the garage. I love the smooth and effortless driving dynamics that EV offers for daily driving. Did not order mine to 'save the world', I ordered it because I actually enjoy driving EVs for daily driving.

I do like the look of the current Leaf, it's a shame the tech is lagging.

Still can't believe they didn't offer a CCS option. I supposed it's a bit of a BETAMAX Vs VHS situation.

text: We were told recently that you break even with emissions at 70,000 mile or 7 years. BUT, we need to consider that the battery will require changing shortly after this time period, at a cost of over ¬£10,000 in most cases. Some cars are requiring batteries early, some later. But for me Ian, it has to be insurance. Insurance companies are writing these cars (EV cars) off with very minor damage. One chap just had a slightly scuffed floor and it was completely written off because the insurance company couldn't tell if the battery had been compromised. Also, why are we seeing so many EV cars catching fire? One poor lady lost her entire house in the States, because her rental Mercedes caught fire and took her house with it. I like the idea of EV cars, but I find them stressful. Is it going to catch fire? Is the insurance going to be too expensive? Am I going to be landed with a huge bill for a new battery? Remember, it only takes ONE cell to short, and we get ourselves into a Thermal Runaway situation, which will engulf the entire vehicle in flames! Plus the elephant in the room is the purchase price. Who can afford them?

text:
If that car had a CCS charging port, it would be a far, far more practical alternative. Though UK charging structure still needs quite a bit of development.

I stuck to my old, very high kilometreage VW Golf IV for the longest of times here in Norway, until it finally just became too expensive to keep it on the road and have it pass MOTs. Thankfully, that coincided with the charging infrastructure really being up to snuff, and after watching lots of very thorough EV tests done by Bj√∏rn Nyland here on YouTube, I felt more than comfortable about making the switch. I think something like 82 % of new cars sold here in Norway last year were EVs (though I bought a demo car from a dealer), so buying an EV here is about as common as...drinking water, really.

text:
Nissan Leaf owners who have cars less than 8 years old- and in many cases WELL under 100,000 kms are having to scrap their cars because there is currently no repair nor replacement batteries available for them. 

Imagine a customer buying an electric vehicle believing that they are saving the environment only to find that their vehicle is considered scrap after less than 60,000 miles and 8 year‚Äôs worth of service. 

Most gas powered cars in production today should EASILY make it to over 200,000 kms and 15 years worth of use. As for other electric vehicles, the general consensus is that the vehicles are scrap once the battery is worn out because at that point, a replacement battery and the installation will surpass the value of the vehicle. Yes, there are some makes and models that provide better life from their vehicles, but those are offset by the ones that are write-offs because of what should be relatively simple repairs or battery failure.
author: @jaymiller6009

text:
This guy barely knows what he's talking about. He did find and grab a very degraded Leaf, but that's not super common or a good example of what someone would drive with a battery that degraded without planning to replace the battery already. Someone who had no plan of replacing the battery would look for one with little degradation. There are plenty of people who have upgraded the 2011 Leaf to a used 40kwh battery for 3-5k (120-150 mile range). Even people who have NEVER worked on cars before have done the battery swap in driveways. For a little more you can upgrade to a 62kwh battery as well, and get around 200 miles, sometimes more.

The Leaf not having thermal management is actually the main reason there have been almost 0 Leaf battery fires. If the thermal management fails in the slightest in a Tesla, that's usually when you get Tesla fires if the design of their batteries get too hot.

The future Leaf's are possibly switching to Lithium Iron Posphate which those type of batteries degrade a LOT less (last about 20 years), and can take a beating in terms of heat better as well. Also Lithium Iron Posphate batteries are literally not flammable, like Lithium ION or Lithium Cobolt (which is no longer made already due to the negative environmental impacts) which are both EXTREMELY EXTREMELY flammable. Another option in the makes by Toyota is Solid State Batteries which same is leaps and bounds better than Lithium ION.

text:
That's why I did my due diligence before purchasing my Leaf. 
In the 80s I went for a ride in a converted ICE vehicle and was sold on the concept. 
I waited until the lizard battery came out. I found one that had all the battery bars for less than $10,000 in 2016. I was told I couldn't make long trips, but I did make a trip of 1,600  miles, round trip, early on.
The Leaf is now 10 years old with over 126,000 miles and 25% degradation. At this point I don't take long trips and 50 miles is more than adequate for my needs as a retiree. I was looking to the future when I wouldn't drive as much. Most driving is 12 to 24 miles a day. It may be the last car I own. 
It's a great little car for charging at home and local traveling. 
The new Leaf has longer range and would make a less expensive alternative here in the Northwest. 
I don't see a battery swap as totaling the vehicle,  but as a being a less expensive alternative to buying a new car. I don't view an item that loses value year after year an investment. I purchased it as I knew it would be less expensive to operate. It has served me well.

author: @wrongbeans

text:
I think you missed the *other* major, expensive fault with these cars: the On Board Charger.

The 2010-2013 Leaf on-board charger is known to fail and is an expensive fix. If you're lucky and have the know-how, it can be repaired cheaply with a bit of work, but a full replacement is over $3k.

When the on board charger fails, you can only charge the car on DC ChaDeMo. You won't be able to charge at home.

Otherwise a fair review. I have a 2012 Leaf, which I bought in July last year. It has just dropped to 9 bars. So far so good with it. It does help that it is from a cooler climate (Canberra, Australia) and only has 53,000km on the clock. Now that it's in Sydney it's degrading mildly faster but it only does occasional short trips now.

Love mine, but agree that the first gen leaf should be avoided. And the fact that new leafs STILL come with no thermal management and ChaDeMo is appalling, which is why when we bought our new EV this year we picked the BYD Atto 3 (which has been fabulous). It's a pity, because the Nissan is the OG, it's the grand daddy, and it is damn well built.

Oh, the heater in the Leaf is grossly inefficient. It'll sap range something fierce. I've seen mine draw 4500 Watts, compared to my Atto's heat pump drawing a little over 1000 at worst.

text: I argue that it‚Äôs not a fundamental flaw, it‚Äôs the premise that the early leaf does not meet American consumer specifications. That is, we want long range and are so ideologically dependent on gas. I have put 40k on my 2012 through commuting to Ann Arbor with Michigan winters with zero issues. It‚Äôs close to 75k now. On average I spend $15 dollars a month on subsidized electricity in Anna arbor. Secondly, if I were to be unable to leave my rural area because of a bad winter, well then I pull out my  2021 4 runnerTRD Pro. Thus, 95% of my driving annually, is done by the leaf and saving me a tremendous amount of money. I literally save more money having a gas powered car on storage insurance rate with an EV versus if I were to drive my 4runner daily at $70 a tank of gas weekly. Great show! But a separate analysis needs to be conducted relative to your daily commute audience‚Äîthe leaf is not designed for long road trips, hence it meets its purpose to save money for your normal commutes and even in austere weather. Also, the front wheel drive does just fine in heavy snow. Just slap some all weather tires for about $60 a piece. Another argument on why the leaf is great‚ÄîITS CHEAP!!

text:
Owning 2013 Leaf S with Chademo since 2020 in Ukraine, did 28k miles on it already. All time with A/C on, without ECO and without 'slow driving', just enjoying the car. When bought it was 83.5% SOH (18kw/h usable) and now 76% SOH (16.8kw/h ~ usable). 99% of time charge to 100% but never was discharging it to 'turtle' state, never left it even for a day being charged to 100% or discharged less than 20%, like 99% of charges made at home with 220V with it's own brick (which charges around 2.2kw/h). The only problem I was experiencing - it's suspension. Car has 86000 miles on it by this time.

Big part missed is difference between 2011-2012 and 2013-2017 cars and of course the one with 30kwt battery. ZE0 - 11-12', AZE0 - 13-17', BZE0 - 13-17' but with 30kwt.
ZE0 is the worst one, it looks identical visually but technically it's just another car, another battery chemistry (and another battery case/connections as well), another motor, another charger, another wiring, just really different car and it's degradation yeah, not good at all + charger is known to be 'fried' and find a replacement is an expensive headache, in fact any spare part which is different from AZE0 is hard and expensive to find.
But starting from AZE0 it's really different, battery much more reliable (as for me my stats are not bad and I've seen plenty of better ones here with same age), charger is reliable and can handle up to 6.6kw/h AC (seems as a joke nowdays but it's better than default 3.3), anything not related to battery/bodywork is quite easy and cheap to find (maybe except suspension, even though it's simple it still quite pricy), heater works like immediately + if it is a SV/SL trim you get efficient heat pump which reduces power usage for heating approx by 15-20%.

For most people in US I guess car under 10k is not a thing so Leaf should be avoided in this case but if you have only up to 8k for a car, charge plug at home and it fits your range - it is just pefrect. Air cooling will be a problem only for extreme hot temperatures and if you are using more than 1 DC charge in a row. For all time all problems I had is with suspension (I guess our shity roads also aaffected it :D) and that's it, after fixing suspension it became just perfect for my needs again. Next one will be tesla for sure but that's some time later.

P.s. As for BZE0 (the one with 30kwt pack) should be avoided at all costs, Nissan really failed with software and these cars were degrading super fast because of it, they had a campaign but not a lot of cars been 'updated' since you can't just do it by yourself as in Tesla, a lot of cars still on old firmware + after update battery still already degraded, in other parts - it's the same as AZE0.
author: @oleksiikobzar5727

text:
Hello, by having a vehicle over 10 years old and a battery with a gross capacity of 24Kwh for 21Kwh useful, with more than 100,000km, there is a way to have a battery that is quite worn out...


The manufacturers make guarantees which can indicate the probable degradation of the battery, for the leaf 24Kwh is 5 years or 100000Km, we can therefore deduce with this guarantee that the maximum loss of capacity over 5 years is 30%.
If the loss of capacity is linear, we would have a 60% loss of capacity, fortunately this is not the case, we must rather be at a 45% loss of capacity. With a typical average consumption of 15Kwh/100Km, we can conclude that with the remaining 10 to 12Kwh, we can travel 77Km by draining the battery, moreover what I indicate is quite close to what you have on the meter.

For a vehicle with such degradation it is preferable to change the battery with one having a larger capacity and recycle the old one into a stationary battery.

This vehicle is therefore good to buy, as long as we know what we are going to do, so to say that we should not buy is a total mistake.

Sincerely.

text:
You should make a correction to this video because these vehicles are actually not air-cooled, they are passively cooled there's a difference.

Air cooled cars have better radiators and fans to assist in forced air induction, like the Nissan ENV200. Whilst passively cooled EVs simply radiate heat through the cars body (think heat radiation through the chassis, metal plates or special "cooling skin") or through a basic radiator with no fans, as the leaf does. Hence why the leaf overheats more often when not in motion.

If these cars get short-range and you're planning a longer trip just pop into one of these exchange places and get a new battery for an extended journey.

I'm thinking of this car in mind and the BMW i3 and practically any other car that can get you less than 200 miles of range.

text: NOT air-cooled.  There is NO FLOW of any cooling agent (not even air) through the battery pack.  Convection of heat across case surface ONLY.  That‚Äôs the problem.  There ARE air-cooled batteries (early VW‚Äôs for example).  Convection is the poorest cooling capability and is why old, GEN1 Leaf‚Äôs must be carefully checked for battery health.

text: Hang on, you‚Äôre completely missing a big part of the story here:  Yes, the 2011 - 2012 are a hard pass, but starting around March 2013, they greatly improved the battery and added an optional heat pump. The whole family loves it, and now my son drives it to college every day, and the battery is still at 80% of its original capacity.  The realistic 100% range is still 70+ miles. text: I think we are going to find this to be common with all EV's as they get to be 10-15 years old, even with low mileage.   Batteries degrade even if you do not drive them much.   We see this with everything in our lives be it laptops, phones.   The battery life and replacement really needs to be factored into the "maintenance" and long term ownership of these cars.   Not everyone buys a new car every 3-5 years and many of us can only afford used ones that are 5+ years old and keep them for many years afterwards.  This whole "lower cost of maintenance" for the early years of EV's is really just a myth for people that have this cars, even low mileage cars, as they age.   Battery replacement is real thing that everyone seems to conveniently avoid talking about that we need to start discussing.
author: @markmonroe7330

text:
Loved my Leaf.  Taking care of that battery is key.  Slow AC charge it, keep it out of the sun and heat as much as you can and the batteries will live a lot longer.  The price to replace these batteries is still very high and while you can get a larger capacity battery for them the cost will still be questionable.  One of the glaring deficiencies in the EV market are the shops that do the repairs.  It is a problem that is only going to grow.  Insurance companies too often are salvaging vehicles because they can't get them recertified and repaired so they write them off.  The new Leaf being sold today is still air cooled.  I don't know what changes Nissan has made to address the degradation in the currently sold new cars, but I don't hear as much complaining today.  It is dead end technology.  Nissan needs a serious update to this car which it does not appear they will be doing. 

While not a good idea to DCFC these things much to add insult to injury the DCFC plug is Chademo so there aren't as many places to charge when away.  You have to make sure the Leaf is even equipped with the DCFC plug because it wasn't standard equipment until later.   If you only drive local short distances, can keep the vehicle garaged and out of the heat, and AC slow charge it the Leaf with a new battery would still work for people, but that is a lot of conditions to be met for it to make sense now.
author: @Longsnowsm

text:
Good news about the Nissan Leaf. I own both a 15 and a 16 Nissan Leaf. the 15 has 54K and still has 11 bars. It was from the San Francisco area and was never DC fast charged. My wife and I live in the Washington State and my wife will drive this Leaf all day long and still go over 80 miles in her daily commutes. If She uses freeway only, the range will degrade to about 60. Around town is the key. For example, our newer 16 Leaf has 43K on it and still has all 12 battery life meter bars. If I drive around town and no freeway. I can go over 90 miles on one charge.  It's an amazing bargain if you have a secondary vehicle for out of town trips, only use the Leaf for daily short commutes, and then plug in at home with a level 1 or 2 charger. Gas prices here in Washington state are hovering around 5 bucks a gallon, but my wife hasn't had to use a drop of gas in the last 6 months since owning the Leaf. They are peppy quiet and comfortable and can be had for under 8K. 
On a side note, I almost bought a third 2015 Leaf at auction. It had over 120K on it and still had 10 battery life bars. I was hoping to get for under 2k, but it went for 3k.

author: @lavectech

text: Good to see a new vid from you after all this time. Interesting to see the costs in the uk. In New Zealand the government has just changed the rules over EVs, and EV owners now need to pay road user charges, and get no rebates when purchasing a new EV. So EV owners have to pay tax  for each km they travel ,to pay for the roads. Whereas petrol car owners pay this tax in the fuel cost, so don't need to pay per km. So it doesn't really work out any cheaper to own an EV, and with increasing electricity prices, it will likely be more expensive, especially if using charging stations. WE were going to get an EV, but now will probably get a hybrid or petrol only car.
author: @home-space

text: Last year we got a 12-bar Nissan Leaf from 2014 that had done 60k miles. Treat it right and it will last. As for electricity, we were on a British gas standard tariff at 30p pkwh but they do an ev tariff from 12 to 5am for 10p a kwh so we moved to that (12 till 5 for anything electric not justy a car) . So there are savings to be had if you can change. It can do 90 miles on a full charge in summer but we use it for journeys of 30 miles each way max and it's fine (winter did see a 20% drop overall in the number of miles we got on a charge) with a nice drive. For over 30 mile journeys (like trips to the coast, Scotland, wales etc) we take the old diesel out of mothballs and use that..

text:
House seems to be looking nice Jake.
As for the car , you need to dump whatever you have been told or think you know about fast charging damaging batteries as you are very mistaken.
You will have no issues using fast chargers while you are out and about on longer journeys.
Use your charger at home overnight to charge fully and charge out and about on fast chargers on your IKEA trips between 20 and 80 % .. it's pointless going above that as the charge speed drops dramatically once you get to 80% .. and in fact the battery likes to be at least decent temperature before you start charging to get the better speeds.
If it does get too hot , the car will simply drop the charging speed.

I know people that have exclusively fast charged on public chargers and have done 100-150k plus mileage and never once slow home charged .. I exclusively use public fast chargers with my i-pace as I can't charge at home and have no battery issues.

There is a lot of wrong information being spread around about EV charging and it's not helpful at all.

Good luck with the car mate üëç

text:
nissan EV tech here, watch out for corroded brakes [due to lack of use], it gets expensive if you need to renew them. on a manual handbrake version, reverse on a roadtest + gently brake, squeaking or shuddering means seized parts, not much change out of ¬£1k for a full hit.
check the front brakes at 40+MPH, any shaking of steering wheel on moderate brake application - front discs corroded/warped, the discs ain't cheap
on the mk1 [zeo] , heaters pack in [¬£3k], mk2 [ze1], windscreen leaks cause electrical mayhem, so check the carpets are dry.   oh, + get your recalls done, 1 stops your mechanic getting electrocuted, 1 stops the steering falling out, + loads of software updates, 1 even changes the dash to tell you that there is more miles in tank...

text: Interesting video that was quite honest but I do have to disagree with you when you got to the charge times of the car and continued to say welcome to the future. The Nissan leaf is most definitely not the future it really is a re bodied mark 1 leaf with a bigger battery. All the switch gear seats and door cards are lifted straight from the first generation. Great as a second car at a sensible used price. But with the no CCS connector and limited 45 to 50 KW charge speed it‚Äôs not the future. Cars like the Kia EV6  or Hyundai Ioniq 5 are a better representation  of the future with its 800 volt architecture and 250 KW charging speeds charger dependent and CCS CONNECTION.
author: @stephenclay6852

text:
I bought a 2 year old teckna from a Nissan main dealer a couple of years ago. It had 15k on the clock. Despite it having a full charge, by the time I had made the 15 mile trip home it had almost run out of charge. Must just be me, I thought, so I charged it up and used it on the school run the next morning. We had just moved so the school run was 21 miles. At 20 miles I had to go to economy mode or we wouldn't have made it. I rang Nissan and returned the car less than 24 hours after picking it up, they hadn't even sent off the paperwork.
That experience has really put me off EV's and I couldn't justify buying one as a main car. As Matt mentions, spending tens of thousands on a second car for what is essentially a local runaround, is too much for me.

text: I love ICE cars for fun but electric is certainly the future and I think it's a good thing. text: I'm relieved you like it Matt.  I watch most of your videos and respect your opinion.   I  put a deposit on a 2021 e+ Tekna today.  13k miles for ¬£19,800 with a optional bike rack included.  It's almost a purely financial decision for me because 1. It's dropped most of it's value from new and I intend to run it for 8+ years 2. I can get 10p per KWH on OVO which makes it 2-3p per mile 3. Servicing costs are v low 4. There is very little to go wrong with it so I hope it will be more reliable.  5. It's ready for vehicle to grid when the UK starts allowing that.  Hopefully in 2025.  Those who have done that already through trials can make c¬£800 a year by selling energy back to the grid when it is more expensive.  My wife and I will share it and whoever is driving most that day will take it as long as they're not driving 200 miles+ in a day which seems highly unlikely.  I personally think that EV used prices are relatively low at the moment due to the perception of high energy costs.  I think that will settle down in the long run.  Keep up the good work on the channel!

text:
Bear in mind this is probably the WORST EV you can get for any amount of money. It is overpriced, dining out on past glories, air cooled rubbish battery management, Nissan still persists with the almost extinct "chademo" charging connector. There are plenty of better alternatives, both new and second-hand.  Primarily Tesla, simply because you get so much bang for your buck - not least a mature reliable and effortless widespread charging network. Big Battery Teslas will charger at 250kw and smaller battery ones manage 180kw. This is extremely fast. Then MG have three great options - the MG ZS, MG5 (estate) and the new MG4 Hatch. All three are compelling with that "everything" 7 year warranty. I had a very very close look at the new generation Fiat 500 EV last summer and it was an absolutely fantastic little car  though not sure if the battery management is similar to the Nissan - at least it does have CCS charging as standard. 
You mentioned the Leaf is forty grand and I checked the top spec biggest battery item is now ¬£36.5k probably as a result of the recent Tesla price drops. Kia and Hyundai are also worth looking at but be careful to interrogate the dealers about the cost of servicing - the 40k service is the thick end of a Grand - and for what exactly? EVs are not for everyone but for many, they have a place and overall, are peanuts to run compared to the oil burners. Another great review - thanks!

text:
I think this really highlights the issue with EVs.  If you do plenty of miles and hence you need a (half) decent range then you will be looking at the SUV types which must be 3-500KG heavier than an equivalent car using dinosaur fuelled vehicle just in battery weight.  Simple laws of physics indicate that this is going to use more energy as this is proportional to the weight moved.
So buying one of these for environmental reasons does not hold water as you have said.  Unfortunatly too many owners confuse the financial cost of their energy with the amount of energy used, conveniently forgetting that a high proportion of the cost of dino' fuel is tax.

If you only do a few miles then one of the smaller cars may be just fine (as long as you're not doing if for environmental reasons) but if you're only doing a few miles per trip is it really worth paying the premium?  It seems these kind of cars carry a premium of around ¬£15,000.  
Quick bit of math's
¬£15,000 = 10,000 Litres of fuel assuming ¬£1.5/L, I actually see it's quite a bit below this at my local ASDA 
10,000L = 2200  Imperial gallons (the proper full size ones rather than the short measures they get in the US of A)
Lets assume we get a really inefficient petrol car which will only average 30MPG, that will take you 66,000 miles 
So even if the electric was free you'd be at least 7 years older before you break even.

I agree there is a lot to like about the driving characteristics of EVs and if that's what is leading the purchasing decision fair enough, but much as I like a bit of peace and quiet I'd miss the sound of a petrol engine (even some Diesels) particularly one with the correct number of cylinders (which of course is 8).

text: The e-pedal thing is an odd one.  It seems counter intuitive but think of it as the reverse of a normal car.  Think of the brake always being on by default. So you have to put your foot slightly down even going down hill to maintain speed, despite that feeling the opposite of economical.  I tried driving a tesla initially as a normal car but the throttle was like an on off switch because it didn't coast,  it was awful for passengers and me.   Once you get used to it you'll touch the brakes once a week.  It is the way forward. You just have to modulate throttle inputs to increase or decrease the rate of slowing down. Without any throttle its like the hand brake is on in a normal car.

text:
We bought a 2015 Leaf 24 kWh in late 2015, it was an excellent car for what we needed, it was my wife's commuter, not one issue. Fast forward to early 2020 I decided to go full EV taking both our cars EV. 

We'd had such a good experience with the Leaf we had, the  40 kWh Leaf was an obvious choice. How wrong was I, it was an absolute pile of garbage. It couldn't cope with more than one rapid charge a day, it has endless issues Nissan couldn't be bothered to fix and in the 18 months I had the months I had it, it suffered 20% battery degradation. 

Thanks to the barmy UK used market I traded it on for a Tesla Model 3, now that's an amazing EV.

text: My parents got one through the mobility scheme in the UK.   The larger battery version has a pronounced box in the boot which made it really difficult fitting in their wheelchair and other bits needed to move around.    They went for the lesser range one because 90% of the time they just use it around the city where it's excellent.    Holidays however, have become very stressful.   So much so, they rarely drive away on holiday any more due to range anxiety and the plethora of apps required for charging stations in the UK.    They find that once they're out of the city finding working charge points is difficult and managing the apps just isn't easy enough.    I think the infrastructure just isn't there to support ev's as an only vehicle and that's disappointing given how much encouragement is being offered to move to them.     My parent's give their car back in a year's time and have already said they wouldn't have another EV, they will probably look for some form of hybrid.

text:
My biggest issues with EV‚Äôs is longevity and how ‚Äúgreen‚Äù they are.

If the battery needs replacing outside of warranty it effectively writes the car off. I‚Äôve heard it costs ‚Ç¨20,000 for a replacement battery on a Tesla, so it‚Äôs probably considerably more on a Mercedes or BMW.

I also find the idea that EV‚Äôs are the solution to transport emissions infuriating. At best they produce the same amount of greenhouse gases in production as a normal car at 150,000 miles and at that point the battery needs replacing, adding more greenhouse gases.

As a result EV‚Äôs get seen more as white goods that get scrapped every 6-10 years which would lead to a rise in EV production ergo making transport emissions worse than if we stuck with petrol/diesels.

text: Nice balanced review. I own the MG5 EV and I find it a really nice car. The only downside of EV ownership to me is the poor state of the charging network. The amount of chargers is not the main issue, it is the reliability of the chargers. You can plan your route, get to your chosen charger and it is out of order and that can happen more often than people like to admit. Hopefully in the future things will improve. I do not have a home charger so I do charge using the 3 pin plug (granny charger) this suits my needs as I only need a full battery once a week. As far as range goes mine is supposed to do 214 miles and in summer it will easily surpass that but in winter I can be looking at between 160 to 180 depending on the weather.

text: I don't really know all the differences between European and American Leafs, but my Leaf charges at a max rate of 100kw and it takes 30 minutes 20% to 80%. I rely completely on public infrastructure and I haven't found the charging time to be an issue, just 15-20 minutes at a fast charger and I'm good for the week. American Leafs claim a 62kwh battery size and from that I usually get 210 miles from the claimed 215 mile range (although I do live in an area where I have to take a highway to get anywhere). From my experience, range is great (well for me at least), charging times are good, and where I live it's really easy to find a charger it can use.

text:
I'm a 39 year old male Christian man, 6"2, bald but decent looking (I got 7-8.5 on photofeeler), well travelled, level headed, down to earth etc but I am brown skinned. This is something many will not admit to but race plays a crucial factor. White women generally are not into brown or dark skin. People prefer their own race and that's just how it is. I have to accept that sadly but this is the major reason as to why I'm single. 

It may not be too late to meet someone but I haven't even come close to being in a relationship for years now. I rarely even meet someone I want to pursue. The few I do aren't into me and the ones that are, I'm not into. There always seems to be something missing. I very rarely get a mutual match on hinge and other dating apps. Meanwhile, people around me are getting together slowly and although there are others in my situation, I am worried about being left on the shelf and being alone for the rest of my life. I don't want to continue living if that's the case. I've tried to lower my standards but that's the worst possible strategy, pretending and forcing yourself to like someone you know you're not into. 

With no one to share my life with, my existence is very lonely and empty. I have full time work but it's not fulfilling at all. I have my own home, a nice car, my health for which of course I'm grateful but I struggle to see hope in the future at this point.

author: @chasb441

text:
Another great and sincere review Thanks Matt.

I work on many brands of cars, I've driven many EV's and can say without a doubt that the Leaf is my favorite EV, Some like the Telsa are way over priced and so boring, I'm not sold on the idea of only one power source, I think we should all have a choice, EV owners seem to think that petrol and diesel should go away completely, I think that would be a massive mistake, Cars can easily live 30 years with proper maintenence, so why be forced to scrap them down the road, That's a very negative thing to do in the Tree hugging world we live in, kinda like the scrappage scheme where good cars got scrapped for no reason but a Govt pay off. 

I love how so many EV owners leave a comment about Loving not having to stop at a petrol station, yet so many on You Tube stop to charge up their EV and grab a coffee and use the toilet, These people make no sense at all, everybody has to use a toilet sometime and the love for coffee has gone through the roof, Charging an EV on the motorway is no different to stopping to fill up with petrol except it takes longer.
 
I'm sure Id hate plugging in my car every night just in case I needed to go out further a field the next day.

What I really hate is the push from EV owners to try and convince the rest of us that we need an EV, they come across so crass, with positive reviews, the act like they know it all, 
They never seem to bring up range anxiety, they used to tell us how cheap it was to charge up their cars, that seems to have died off now with today's electricity rates, and still they insist and are convinced the price of Electricity will go down, To me that defies all logic, They can install as many wind farms and Solar panels as they want but the price of Electricity will not be falling, the electricity companies will see to that.   

T.B.H. Id be happy to buy a Hydrogen car 5-10 years down the road,  that looks so positive to me and yes the infrastructure has to improve just like with EV chargers. 

Thanks for listening.

text: Hi Matt, I test-drove a Jaguar i-pace the other day, it was a 2018 plate with 39,000 miles on the clock. I loved the car but then I did a little more research work. I discovered that the car had depreciated over half of its list price in less than five years ( approx ¬£29,000 ) more than a similarly priced petrol/diesel equivalent. The battery is only covered for 8 years of manufacturer warranty !!!!!! so in three years if the battery died I would have to pay approximately ¬£8000 - ¬£ 10000 for a new one. The tax incentives that the government initially gave to get everybody into an EV are slowly being taken away and are now saying that from 2025 all-electric cars will have to pay VED at the standard road tax rate furthermore the little government help to have home wall chargers installed is no longer available. With the current price of electricity/availability of suitable charging stations at present, I think I will stick to my trusty 3-year-old diesel car.

text:
Nice mini review - but a few points worthy of note.

The charge lead not fitting is not a thing, or at least, not as you glossed over. The charge leads you carry in the car are all Type-2 connectors for fast (not rapid) charging, and they will fit every Type 2 Fast charger out there - i.e. all of them. The Leaf does, however, use Chademo rapid charging, and that is rarer than the more common CCS rapid chargers, though most rapid charger locations will have at least one or two Chademo capable chargers - the leads on a rapid charger are permanently attached to the charger, and not carried in the car. Is it an issue? Yes, it does limit your options a little as to where to head for a rapid charge - it's worth using an App such as Zap Map to locate suitable chargers - but then that's like charging any other EV (other than Tesla with their own Supercharging network).

Range on the 60kwh version: - we drive a 40kwh version, and our achievable range is around 130 miles in the winter, and just over 150 miles in the summer. Given that there is 50% more capacity in the 60kwh (59) version, 190 miles in the winter and around 225 in the summer seems like a reasonable assumption to make.

Ours is on just a 2 year lease - this was us dipping our toe in the EV water to see how we got on - like others, we were concerned that the range wouldn't be enough, and we weren't prepared to fork out on an expensive lease (iPace, EQC etc.) as a taster.

I can say though, that the experience has been great. Much of your review is spot on - it's not a car that feels particularly special. The level of trim is just OK, even in the 'top spec' Tekna - it's not somewhere I love to be - but it is acceptable as a day to day workhorse. My wife, a GP, uses it for the most part, and tends to do a daily commute, plus house visits of 60-70 miles - and for this, it's ideal. Also, as it doesn't scream 'pretentious' , no-one gives it a second glance.

Cost to run? Well, the lease we have costs less than the diesel we were burning in a V60 as my wife's previous car per month. And charging overnight means our cost per mile is just over 2p! Compare that to our XC90, which costs 26p per mile in diesel alone!

If I were to use a rapid charger however, the cost shoots up to nearer 20p a mile - comparable to a diesel estate. But no-one I know consistently charges their EV at a rapid charger - everyone either charges overnight on a cheap tariff, or, worst case, charges at the standard rate - which still equates to around half the price of running a diesel vehicle. Anyone that might not have access to their own electricity supply should look elsewhere until the charging infrastructure is there; at the moment, the operators of rapid chargers are price gouging because they can. Once charging points and rapid chargers become more prolific, the pricing should stabilise at a much lower level.

I'm sure there will be a few (many?) petrol head luddites, who will say in the comments that they will never have an EV, as they're committed to driving their gas guzzling V8's (or more likely 4-pot Fiesta) and they can do 800 miles on a tank of dinosaurs. And these people have obviously never been in an EV, so are talking from a totally ignorant stand point. Anyone who has ever been in an EV would never make such blanket statements - they would at least acknowledge that the future is electric, whether we want it or not. Yes, it might not be for them just yet - but as sure as eggs are eggs EVs are here to stay, and ICE, certainly as far as personal transport goes, is heading the way of the steam locomotive.

Back to the Leaf - a few things I love, and a few things I don't like.

I love the fact that I've never had to deice this car - not once! It's set to pre-condition itself every morning, so you step into a perfectly warm car (or cool in the summer), with the heated seats and steering wheel up to temperature too.

I love the fact that I've never had to visit a petrol station.

I love the fact that my destination has been sent from my phone to the SatNav, so that's already to go too.

I don't like the vague steering (though it's much better since we switched over to Goodyear All Seasons rather than the ECO tyres it comes with).

I hate the 'Pro-Pilot' autosteer - which has tried to kill me a couple of times.

Someone asked about heating hitting range - yes it does, but not as much as you might think. The V2 Tekna (not sure about other models) has a heat pump for heating, so is very efficient, and also has LED headlamps etc. So it's not so much the heating on these newer Leafs that hits the range, but just the battery temperature - colder batteries charge/discharge less efficiently, and this has the greatest bearing on range. 

And that's about it - its a very average car, that just happens to be electric - and it's the electric side of things that makes it. Is it perfect? Far from it - I wouldn't bother trying to do a long journey in it - though plenty of owners do - but when I have access to other (non EV) cars, for super long trips we take one of those - as I said earlier, rapid charging is a similar cost to running on diesel, so why would I take an average car on a long trip, when I can drive in comfort/style? It's not so much the 'hassle' of charging vs filling up with petrol/diesel - just the comfort/fun I'd rather have on a longer run. For anything less than 150 miles though, it's the Leaf every time, as it's just so cheap to run!

Oh, and for avoidance of doubt, I'm not an EV evangelist, I simply state what I know, EV's are the future, whether we like, or want to admit it, or not. We run two other cars, an XC90 oil burner, and a Nissan 370Z - both at other extremes from the Leaf, and we use them for very different tasks. But as a day-to-day runabout, the Leaf is actually difficult to beat.

text:
I have exactly one of these (71 plate e+ Tekna). Tried all the cheaper EVs, wasn't expecting to like it but better ride, spec, space, range and performance than all of them. Cheaper too (was ¬£28k new after discounts, grant, etc).  It's not exciting but just super easy to live with, it's become the car we use 95% of the time as we can get enough luggage in for family trips and propilot makes motorway driving very relaxed. Enough range that for the vast majority of journeys you just don't need to care about eco driving, or being miserly with the heating. 

e+ can charge a bit quicker (70kW-ish) at many rapids than the smaller battery ones. Did 310 miles yesterday and just did 3 very brief stops when I felt like a comfort break or to grab a sandwich, put it on charge for 10-15 mins each time. No broken chargers, no waiting, all very easy. Still got home with 10% left.

author: @harrycalibra

text: The older Leafs (Leaves?) in particular can make good buys if you get one cheap enough. Because of their simplicity (in EV terms) they are an easy and inexpensive EV on which to have a battery pack refurbishment carried out. One particular Leaf owner took his 10 year old example to a well known independent EV specialist in Gloucestershire for a battery pack refurb, and the work took 4 hours, and cost ¬£500. A cheap Mk 1 Leaf could readily provide less than 3p per mile motoring on an off-peak EV tariff. Ok, not everyone goes for the Miss Marple body styling, but it sure saves a packet over buying petrol or using public transport. Plus there are now a number of aftermarket mods for the Mk 1 Leaf.....  I don't own a Leaf personally, but I use Octopus Intelligent to charge my EV, and that gives me 6 hours per night at 10p per kwh. A full charge after a week of driving normally costs me around ¬£7. The per mile cost is around 3 to 3.5p, which works out at about a 7th of the cost of buying petrol..... Public charging costs a lot more, but even then, the cost can be reduced by subscribing to the charge network you want to use. And if you have a Sainsburys near you, they still offer free charging.....
author: @Brian-om2hh

text:
I have a leaf and the one you are driving is a gen 5 and not a gen 2. The first 3 gens all used the same body style while the later 2 used the newer body style. 
I have a gen 3, 30kwh battery and it's an excellent car. I am a regular up and down the motorway and have done 20k miles in it in the last 2 years. 
It is old tech, and second hand prices reflect that. But all of the rapids I go to have the correct connector and more are going in daily. The situation today is miles different/better to that from when I bought the car two years ago. 
Having a plug at home really helps and you are absolutely wrong in saying that 100 miles is not good enough. How often do you actually drive that far before getting home? I suspect far less than you think. 
I agree that gen 1 (2011) cars have problem batteries, something that nissan should have dealt with with a battery upgrade program. But there is a 3rd party network who do upgrades, but virtually the majority of cars never need it. 
If I had to read the body language, I would say that you don't quite understand the whole EV thing yet.

Buying secondhand would give any buyer a dilemma as when you go to trade in or resell what would you expect to get vs the petrol equivalent so my thoughts would be that the equivalent to a Leaf new would be less than 40k in petrol form and then after six years when all warranty etc are gone for the petrol or EV I can see the petrol being of higher value‚Ä¶.

I recently did a wee drive over to Ayrshire on the weekend there and one of the charging hubs (Kilmarnock Arena) it had 4 free rapid chargers, 1 of them the CCS wasn't working but Chademo was working on the unit so was pretty much only for Leafs. text: The Nissan Leaf (all generations) suffers from a lack of thermal management of the batteries, there is no active cooling or heating of the batteries which leads to quicker degradation of the battery pack over time. I own a couple of the 1st gen Leaf that have had their batteries replaced under warranty after only a couple of years due to this. When out of warranty the battery replacement doesn't make fiscal sense as you can pick up a used one for less than it would cost to replace the battery pack. While the range is low on the 1st gen by modern standards, as long as you have home charging and you don't need to run all day on the motorways you will find it's a great city car with more than enough range for most folks daily round trip needs.

text:
Once you go electric there's no going back. I was sold on my first test drive of an electric (the old Leaf) and ended up getting an eGolf three years ago. I'm about to replace it and will probably go for the Leaf. The torque and the smoothness are better even than the best Mercedes, Jaguar or Bentley, and the quietness (it's not quite silent, especially under hard acceleration, when there's a sci-fi whistling sound from the motor) is a delight. No more stupid loud engine noises. No vibration from a clunky dinosaur petrol engine. It's flipping great. 

The only negatives - charging time; can't just stop in a station, fill up and be off after five minutes. I always charge at home using the solar panels on the roof of  my house, but occasionally have to charge when I'm out and about. This means charging has to be planned ahead of time. 

This brings me to point 2 - occupied charging points. Right now charging points are limited and the adoption of electric vehicles has outpaced the number of chargers. A mass installation of public chargers needs to be implemented. It's annoying enough to find all the chargers occupied by other electric vehicles, but when some dick in an ICE car parks in one, out of spite, well, karma, baby. Key karma. Tyre karma. Etc.

Point 3 - range. That's why I leased a car with 85 miles or range.  I'm expecting 500 mile range in five years' time and probably a 1000 or more range  within a decade. But right now we're around 250 miles. 

So those few things sound like deal breakers. But they're really not. For ninety-five per cent of daily driving you'll never need to concern yourself with range or long charging times. More workplaces are installing chargers (mine has twenty chargers in the car park) and you can plug into a wall socket, but your charging time will take longer.

Electric cars are the future and for all the naysayers (people who've never driven an electric car) I always ask "what's your solution to the end of oil? What's going to replace it?" I still haven't received a valid answer.

text:
At 0:56 you state the car applies the brakes when you lift off the accelerator. NOT SO: it goes into a regenerative braking mode and recovers kinetic energy back to electricity using the motors. IT DOES NOT apply the brakes. It's a sort-of electric equivalent to engine braking in an IC motor.
Also I think you've mixed your units up over the range. You state 250 miles, but I think you'll find it's about 170miles = 250Km.

text: If I have the money to use my Model 3 reservation, made 31st March 2016, here in the UK, I will buy or lease one when it arrives on these shores in 2019. I am sure it will have been worth the wait  I also want to support Tesla for Elon's dogged determination in the face of small and negative thinking little beings, and for his vision.  By the way, let's get just a wee more accurate about the 2018 Leaf's range - the standard battery will likely provide about 150 miles. Don't get confused by the Japanese standard of measurement, which is akin to the European one. The American EPA rating is closer to the truth.  Aside from these things, the Leaf still looks like a Leaf, though I can say I now regard the new styling as reasonably attractive instead of relatively butt ugly. Still no comparison to the GORGEOUS Model III.  The Leaf, however, will be a good deal more affordable for many to buy, compared to all but the most basic Model III configuration.  I think the Leaf now has a good deal more to recommend it, and aside from all this, let's keep in mind that Tesla is and will not be "threatened" by any other EVs; They are light years ahead of the curve. In the end, the more EVs on the road, the better it will be for our current environment, - planet Earth. So, here's to the proliferation of EVs!

text:
The question is very simple: if you live in a city, would you rather walk on streets surrounded by EVs or by ICE cars? The quicker we change to EVs the better for all and each of us.

The world is actually already on a big move anyways, with China/India/Pakistan getting larger and larger share of EV in new vehicles, and especially EV bikes ‚Äî which could be a good solution for crowded European cities, too.

The more you try to do "business as usual", the more risk you're running to be left behind. At some point in time there could be the only thing left as business in the UK: tourism. Showing off Stonehenge to rich Chinese and Indian tourists...

text: When a gas/diesel car battery dies, it isn't usually a problem until you turn the engine off.  Even at that, we just jump-start it from any other vehicle and we're on our way in 5 min.  It looks like this vehicle got towed.  So, when your teen daughter is on her way home at night and runs low on charge, she has to wait hours(?) for an unscrupulous technician to tow her car to the shop and wait 12 hours for it to charge enough to get home? That's assuming the towing person can find a compatible charging station and/or adapter.  You'll probably be charged 2x as much to charge the battery plus an exorbitant fee for any adapters needed.  Does your auto club include a hotel room for the night and a day's salary while you wait for the battery to charge?  Sounds expensive!

text:
the issue is that the trip computer predicts the distance based obviously on available battery capacity but also on speed and how aggressive you press the throttle, it wouldn't be uncommon for the trip computer to be 20 miles off or more. I drove this car for 3 years, , it was a 2015, they updated it in 2013 with heat pump and some other things like a dedicated Heat on/off button which was very convenient. 

The best way to describe driving an electric car is when you're driving down the motorway in most electric cars, it's as if you're driving a petrol or diesel with a hole in the tank, smaller battery cars feels like the hole is bigger, if that makes sense ?

Electric cars are good 2nd hand buys for 2nd family cars if only doing short trips then again if you're only doing short trips you can get a cheaper petrol that will travel anywhere any time without the hassle of public charging because it is a right pain in the arse after the novelty wears off and it wears off quickly. 

I would say even the latest electric cars are good for 2nd family cars with an ICE car at home but why would you pay so much ? it makes no economic sense and you will be shocked at trade in. 

I'm in the position now where my 2.5 year old Volkswagen Id.3 77 kwh is worthless because no one wants to take the car as trade in unless I give it away , it was 41 K Euro's new ( Ireland prices ) and I was offered between 11k and 15K Euro's max.

So what this tells me also is that high spec and having a larger battery makes no difference, so if you want to buy an electric car and pay a lot more for the larger battery option be warned that this adds no value to the trade in price so my advice is buy the cheapest EV you can get if you want one, in other words, if there's 2 battery options, one 55 Kwh and the other 77 Kwh but the 55 Kwh because the 77 Kwh adds no value when you trade it in but then you're left with even less range, but my advice is save the money and don't buy electric car to begin with as you are not going to save money or the Earth !

I will have to wait until the PCP is up and hope some dealer will just take it back and I can buy a real car again after 9 years and 3rd EV later finally realising it's a huge financial mistake buying an electric car, although the real issue is that they don't want electric cars because they can't sell them. So I might have to set fire to it and claim the insurance as right now there literally is no way to get rid of it. ( joke ) at the end of the PCP I will be over 20,000 kms over the limit times whatever the extra mileage charge is so at that rate I'll have to pay to hand it back but another lesson to be learned, don't buy new cars, especially Electric and do not go with PCP finance, it's a bottomless pit !

text:
When has anything with a battery ever 
lasted as long as advertised?

120 miles in marketing speak = 37 miles in real world use. That 120 was under lab conditions at a perfect 70 degrees with a 50lb child driving (alone and naked) with no heating, AC, phone charging, luggage or hills.

And... the battery was brand new. Like with your phone... you can cut that in half after a year of regular usage.

Plus... also like with your phone... the manufacturer will drain your battery with constant "updates" and spying on you... even if you aren't driving.

Why does anyone think EV batteries would behave any different to other batteries???

text: 'Not much that can go wrong with an electric motor' mmm lol !. Guess you never heard of bearings or gear drive trains (yes EVs still have drive train reduction gears and diffs lol) and what about the liquid cooled 3 phase electronic motor control systems/speed control systems/coolant pumps and plumbing for motor/battery cooling and inverters?, or anything else related to its control systems then of which any component going pop means game over for an older EV, especially with anything electrical with 10 years on it!. Most pcb smd caps for example used on motor drive pcb's have a rated life of only 2 to 2.5k hours and @ 1 hour use a day = 8 years mtbf - a very convenient 80 to100k miles for an EV, so all timed to fail around the same time (battery/electrical control systems)... The thing is I really like the idea of electric, they just have to be made with better components such as solid state caps instead of cheap electrolytic ones with 5k+ mtbf, but I doubt they will, EV's are designed to fail, its built in to their components (as for batteries, 10 years is close to end of life for any device really with current technology, so an automatic scrappage timebomb for any EV regardless of usage)... Petrol/diesel vehicle design in the electrical department are no different, except they are easy to re-cap by just removing the easy to access ecu and replacing the capacitors on them (done it myself many times), EV ones are buried in with the motor assembly/liquid cooled and usually require drive system/motor strip downs to get to them so most wont even touch them and those that do charge $$$ in labour alone usually instantly scrapping the vehicle.

text:
I had the updated version leaf in 2015 with heat pump and furthest it would really go on a warm summer day was around 90 miles below motorway speeds, in Winter on Motorway you're be looking at charging around 60 miles or being very close to a charger and it took a long time to charge. 

Now I drive a Volkswagen ID.3 77 Kwh EV and it has a claimed 340 Miles but in reality 217 Miles at decent speeds , so whatever the manufacturer says reduce this by around 35-40%.

I'm driving EV 9 years and won't be buying another, depreciation is an absolute killer, been told by around 5 dealers that they don't want to trade an EV, VW themselves offering me half what I paid after 2.5 years. 

All this in car tech and entertainment is highly distracting and I don't like using the touchscreen to do simple things like change Climate settings or radio, or suffering sluggish software, waiting for it to boot up before you can even access climate settings for example is highly irritating, I hate these systems and it's the worst thing ever to infect the auto industry, big screen for entertainment and even now you will find it hard to find analogue instrument cluster they have mostly changed to hideous looking screens. 

Anyway I test drove a Kia Stonic the other day, a 1.0L 3 cylinder manual petrol and really liked it, functional cockpit, lovely instrument cluster , nice manual climate control, it was so refreshing, most things I need at my fingertips not in menus. The 1.0L 100 Hp engine is more than powerful enough. 

Driving the Manual petrol actually made me smile, it was fun and engaging EV is ultra boring after the novelty wears off but these infotainment systems in many cars now is a huge turn off and frustrating. 

Now I'm finding it very difficult to get rid of the ID3, it was the same with my other 2 electric cars, no one wants them and will offer you very little at trade in.

text:
As a 2-time used EV owner, a 2013 Nissan Leaf is literally the worst case scenario. There are some small-battery cars that do actually surprise you. The Kia Soul EV is an example of that, simply because they actually decided to regulate the battery's temperature with water to extend it's lifespan. Leafs just let the batteries boil in the summer and freeze in the winter. I owned a 2018 Kia Soul EV with an EPA estimated 111 miles of range for almost two years, and the furthest I travelled on a single charge was 118 miles, and the range dropped onto to around 90 miles in the winter. It was genuinely a great car, and even charged at 70 kW from time to time! That charging speed let me recharge in 20-25 minutes, which some other expensive cars are still struggling to reach.
Now I drive a 2017 Chevy Bolt so I can finally reasonably go on road trips, absolutely love it! Although, I miss some features of the Kia Soul. I rarely hit 50 kW when fast charging, usually more around 37 kW. Can take FOREVER to charge. However, the refreshed 2024 Bolt should address this by moving it to the Ultium platform.
One thing is for sure, I will never buy an ICE car!

text: My friend has a 2011 Leaf that predicts 78-82 miles fully charged.  He drives slow and carefully and regularly gets 4.7 miles/kWh. On return it went from 39 to 17 miles and from 6 to 3 bars.  So we used up twice as many "miles" and twice as many bars outbound as we did coming home.  So maybe that is characteristic of a degraded battery? And overall the predictor was about 20% overoptimistic.

text:
I'm 1 minute into this video, and I can already tell you know nothing about electric cars. You sound like an idiot. 

The "guessometer" is exactly what it sounds like -- the range is changing because your driving style or conditions are not optimal, so it's adjusting its best guess from that. If you knew this, you wouldn't be surprised or freaking out about the miles figure change. Go downhill and it'll go back up again just as rapidly. It's not the same as a petrol gauge. Electric range varies based on conditions: grade, driving style, temperature, AC usage etc. etc.

Also, failing to point out early in the video that these old cars with no battery conditioning and old battery chemistry suffer enormously from degradation that modern cars don't is a huge emission. Hope you mention that later in the video.

I bought a 2011 Nissan Leaf for a similarly impressive price as a commuter car a few years ago, and with all the nice premium features it had, it still remains the best per-dollar car I've ever bought. These cars are hugely undervalued -- if the range works for your needs they're an absolute bargain.

text:
I'm glad that a lot of people in the comments are sensible and don't deny the sheer impracticaly of an ev. 
EVs been invented way before than ICEs, and with all that headstart, they are still shit. We just haven't invented that super-battery that would charge in 5 minutes and would last for ~650 km, with heater and other electronic appliances turned on of course, won't dry on its own while just standing there, and wouldn't shrink dramatically the colder it gets.
I get that they are trendy and cool, a lot of them are supercar-tier fast, but those are pros for a very niche strat of the market, and that doesn't excuse car manufactures and even some governments that try to shove EVs down everyone's throats

text:
I had a 2013 Leaf Tekna (the late 2013 upgraded version with LED lights and a few other stuff) that I sold last fall. It had done 105 000 km and still had 12 bars of health. The LeafSpy app showed that the actual health was 86% so just about to lose a bar. It still did 130 km in the summer. Only reason I sold it was the poor winter range and I had a regular need to drive 2 hours there and back, so the car just wasn't keeping up.. That being said I really loved that car. 5 years of ownership and it was such a comfortable and good ride. I replaced it with a cheap 2010 Ford Fiesta 1.6 TDCi and that has been such a downgrade in every conceivable way, except range. Full tank of diesel can get me at least 800 km away from home. 
My next car is likely gonna be a 2018-2020 40 KWh Nissan Leaf Tekna as I wanna go back to the reliability and comfort it has to offer.

text: In 2019, I bought a 2013 Nissan Leaf with a bit over 30,000 km on the odometer. It initially had 11 bars of battery health, which decreased to 10 bars by the time I sold it. I drove it for 1.5 years, covering approximately 10,000 km. During the summer, it offered a range of 100-120 km, while in winter, the range dropped to 80 km. Unfortunately, in Germany, the purchase price was 10,000 Euros, and I sold it for 6,700 Euros. Nonetheless, it served me well for my daily round trip of 28 km to work, and I could easily charge it using a standard Schuko plug in my garage. I appreciated the ability to schedule preheating for every day of the week, and the rear camera proved to be very useful. Additionally, I utilized LeafSpy for monitoring purposes. Overall, it was a great car, but I decided to switch to a Tesla Model 3 Performance in 2021. üôÇ

What the hell am I watching?

Bruv, my fully loaded '19 Camry four cylinder can easily do five hundred miles a tank, and you change the oil every 5,000mi, and tranny fluid every 30,000mi. text: No not really. ALL EV's are rip offs. What can go wrong with a battery pack? Short circuits, really cold or really hot charges, prolonged cold exposure, prolonged hot exposure, water ingress, natural degredation of the cells they only have so many charge cycles regardless of the charge voltage/current, and 100's of other things that on an ICE vehicle you can check the fluids for and there are tell tell signs of failure, battery packs with proprietary charging systems can't and thats the biggest difference. Im a car person and EV's scare trf out of me because you can't just look at it and tell if its going bad. Thats why it doesn't "feel" like anything can go wrong because its all hidden. Love how it says "keepers" implying you don't even own the car, you are just keeping it for the time being and got had pay them for the luxury lol That only works for the leaf, if you have literally anything else you can't see state of charge so easily. Notice how much the dash bullshits you.... making it unreliable af you are clueless as to the TRUE state of the charge not what it wants to tell you it is in the moment. So many reasons to not like EV's, I could go on and on and on. The fact most grid energy comes from coal, means those cars actually run on coal. Which is NO better then gasoline. Also nothing is maintenance free. If they say it is then get in there and look to make sure, usually not, they want you to not do the maintenance and kill it...

text:
Few things as an ex-Leaf owner (2015 version):
‚Ä¢¬†I think the 124 range you mentioned, was the "rated" range, which is about as reliable as the range-o-meter in the dash. I had the Tekna (top spec at the time) and I used to get about 90 miles safely with normal driving style.
‚Ä¢ The range-o-meter was affectionately known as the "guess-o-meter" in the community. It bases the range of current driving so the estimate changes wildly as you drive.
‚Ä¢ I opted for the Tekna model as it had a heat pump for the climate, other models had a resistive heating system that would eat battery!
‚Ä¢ The map in the car used to make me chuckle, especially as I used to potter over to the Trafford Centre a lot and it had the "Manchester Ship Canal" listed as "Manchester Shit Canal" which was classic as there is a sewage works next to the motorway as you went over it.
‚Ä¢ It uses a CHAdeMO rapid charging connector which in the UK is getting harder and harder to find. CCS2 is the standard now and CHAdeMO has been phased out a lot over the past years.

Honestly, when I had the car I loved it. I made some videos on it including charging at rapid stations. When my finance finished I switched to an ICE Ford Fiesta after it and really missed it, but at the time the then "new" Leaf was ridiculously expensive. These days I am in a Model 3 and soon a Model Y as well and it is night and day. Driving down to London I look at the services I use to have to stop at in the Leaf and remember the stop start nature, now the range of the Tesla is longer than I would drive without a break. It was a great car, I used to love the acceleration especially at traffic lights with a Police car next to me, setting the speed limiter to 33MPH and flooring it, I did about 30k miles in it with no charger at home (lived in an apartment block at the time) and I still look back on the car as a great car.

If you bought a used gun metal grey Tekna Leaf with a reg of MK65 KDN, congrats - that was one mine! :D

text:
Max range videos demonstrate that the video maker doesn't grasp the paradigm shift of electric cars. 
When deciding to buy an EV, like any vehicle, the buyer must realistically figure out what he/she needs. In my case I had a 34 mile round trip commute. An EV with 80 miles of range was perfect since it would get me to work and back without damaging the battery by draining it too low. I plugged in when I got home and every morning the car was fully charged again.
A person would only buy a ten year old Leaf with 60 miles of range if they wanted a commuter car or grocery-getter. Running the d@mn thing dry is senseless.
