author: @craigbanks9532

text:
Some extremely useful info regarding batteries: 

There are 3 main different battery technologies that were at some point or another used in EVs. 
Li-Ion, Li-Po, LiFePo4. 
The market right now is almost if not completely exclusively using Li-Ion batteries due to their small size and light weight. 
Basically Li-Po are the lightest and smallest, but also have the worst charge cycle count (how many times you can charge the battery 0-100% before it is considered "bad"). 
LiFePo4 have by far the superior charge cycle count, but are quite bigger and heavier. 

So the happy middle ground is Li-Ion. Many times used in this 18650 or 21700 cell form factor. 

That Nissan Leaf, might have been using Li-Po batteries just by seeing those pouches and how they got swollen. Generally you can expect up to 100-300 cycles out of a Li-Po, 300-1000 out of a Li-Ion and 1500-6000 out of a LiFePo4 battery. 

What is a charge cycle really? 
In theory it is the sum of the partial charge cycles (for example 40-100, 15-100, 50-100, 95-100, these four charges would be 2 full charge cycles, because they sum at 200% of charge need). But that's not the whole story. A battery is happier if it's SoC (state of charge) doesn't fall below 20%. Most importantly it's way happier if it doesn't stay below 20% for extended periods of time (not charging it for a day or two...). It's also happy if it doesn't stay at 100% for extended periods of time. So, if you make sure that the battery isn't close to those extremes, you can extend these charge cycles quite considerably. 
So, for example a Tesla battery of the last year, should have some Li-Ion cells capable of 1000 charge cycles (impressively high for Li-Ion, best on the market). If tesla engineers make sure their reported SoC is slightly different to the real SoC of the battery, making sure to stay away from those extremes, the battery can last up to 3500 smaller charge cycles (25-90%), which is up to 2500 full charge cycles instead of just 1000... 

3500 charge cycles is roughly 10 years somebody might say. And that's pretty much the case if someone totally drains their car daily. However,I don't believe tesla puts so relaxed extremes to their batteries (because they would lose advertised range that way...), so I think it's more like 2000 cycles of 10-90%. 
Roughly 6 years for daily draining. 
Realistically you will use all the battery every 2-3 days if you drive a lot, so... 12-16 years? Something like that. 

Is charge cycle count the only consideration when talking about battery life? 
No... 

Battery ageing occurs no matter what, it's just faster if the battery is empty or full. 

For a Li-Ion battery you can expect 10-15 years of battery life no matter how much you take care of it. 

So. What does it mean for a battery to die? 

In the world of Lithium batteries, a dead battery is a battery that is below 80% if its original capacity. Why is that? 
Basically from 100% to 80% the battery again curve is a straight line, slowly going down in a straight line as the years or the charge cycles pass. 
However at 80% of its original capacity, this straight line becomes a more and more aggressive curve. 

That actually means that after that 80% point, the ageing of the cells occurs faster and faster and faster. You might need 10 years to go to 80%, but you will need 5 years to go to 60%. 2 years to go to 40%. 1 year to go to 10%. 
That's just an example, but these numbers are almost accurate. 

So basically, your battery is still ok at 85%. At 80% starts the downhill and nothing can stop it. 

So, what does that mean for the Nissan Leaf? First of all, the car already has a kind of bad battery technology if they were using Li-Po cells. So, I assume the 100-80% window closed at around 8 years of use at best. Secondly, the battery that now is at 65-70% is considered dead. You can expect month by month to see a slight reduction in mileage. In the next ~2-4 years, the battery will completely die, unable to do much of anything. 
Are 1500¬£ worth it? Meh... Idk... The car works and it's electric... It might not pay itself because there are too few charge cycles remaining...  I mean, for 1500¬£, you get an electric scooter with less range, so... Yeah. It is kind of value for money... I might would have bought this or something similiral and try to fit my own batteries somehow üòÉ 
That would give me 15 full years of way better range... They only bad thing is that these things have lots of factory locks and stuff... I'd really love to be able to put my own batteries on any of the EVs... Imagine having a second full battery in the trunk... Imagine doing that on a new car. 1000km of range. 

Anyways. These were some nice info for Lithium batteries.

text:
I‚Äôd pay $1500 for a leaf with 60 miles of range IF it wasn‚Äôt for Indiana charging $400 a year for a license plate for ANY EV.

I was going to buy a Fiat 500E back when you could get a 3-4yr old one with under 30k miles on it for around $5000.  You‚Äôd have to pay to import it from Georgia but to Chicagoland transport is very cheap.  Less than $1000 I usually pay $400-600 to import cars from Florida (rust free).  

Anyways I wanted it for my wife to drive 2 miles a day for work and to do grocery runs.  But then that year Indiana stabbed me in the face when I went to go renew the plates on my $14k 2.5yr old 20k mile BMW i3 REx plug-in serial hybrid (because it‚Äôs considered an EV).  My parallel plug-in hybrids have been more expensive per year than ICE registration but not $400+.

Anyways I did the math and my wife could get 15mph driving to work and pay only $100 for fuel a year to get to work.  Sure it would tear the engine up which is why I wanted an EV so we compromised and we now own an ‚Äò12 Civic EXL normal ICE car for long distance and backup vehicle driving.  A ‚Äò17 CMax Energi Plug-In for my wife which gets 15-20 miles of EV range and we own a ‚Äò21 Bolt which my wife loves but I regret buying especially when I found out I could have bought a ‚Äò17 Civic Type-R for the same price and that‚Äôs just as much a family car :).  

States are stabbing us in the backs for buying EVs and hybrids because they are loosing money on gas taxes.  Only thing is they aren‚Äôt charging us fairly.  You‚Äôd have to buy a few thousand in gas to pay $300 in taxes on gasoline.  Plus it‚Äôs semi trucks that ruin the roads not light weight EVs.

text:
When you buy a car, how large of a proportion of all trips do you want to be able to use your car for?

80%,90%,99%,99.9%?

Personally, I would aim pretty low. I don't buy a car for the once in maybe a lifetime trip. I buy something that covers just enough and rent for the rest. That allows you to get away with a cheaper car, that's cheaper to run. Instead of driving a van to work because I might move before I sell the car.

Things like that also affect the re-sale value of electrics because those factors still keep the demand down, even if they're less involved on overall maintenance.

text:
My 10 year old Nissan Leaf 24kWh is coming up to 200,000 miles.  Battery on 9 bars, around 75% capacity.  Range maybe 60 miles, was 80 miles when new.  Fairly bullet-proof, the battery and motor have never broken down ever.  Work required is mainly on the suspension and tyres.  My job involves driving round the local area, and I have solar panels at home and at work.

The UK climate is perfect for batteries, mainly 0-20C and it is parked in a garage so that reduces temperature extremes.  I have rapid-charged it loads, didn't seem to be a problem - heavy usage gets the most out of a battery.  An early adopter in the UK was a taxi company in Cornwall which would get them up to 160,000+ miles no problem then sell them because the upholstery was getting tatty.

text:
I'm not knocking the concept but I live in an apartment and there are no chargers here  nor are there at most apartment complexes.  59 miles or roughly 100 km wouldn't be of much use except as a grocery getter in most of Canada.
Also, because of this test he presumably ran without AC or heating.  It was a clear day so no wipers, defogger, deicer.
So unless you live in the most unbelievable temperate climate the 59 miles would virtually never happen.

Until just recently I delivered new cars from dealer to dealer and have driven many, many electric cars or hybrids.  
If you do not have a place to plug in at home or at work then a plug-in hybrid is the best car to have until the area you live and work in has the properly supported infrastructure.

text:
The biggest thing about a car like this, is what if I want to hop on the highway and go to a park 35 miles away? Even brand new the old Leaf might not make it home. This used example definitely not.

EVs in general are just problematic in their economics, yes if you have a few mile daily jaunt, sure you are fine. And if you are getting a brand new one which much better range than the old leaf, you are fine with a 100 mile daily commute. But the moment you want to go for a road trip you have to rent or own an ICE car to do that. Or plan out charging stops which are gonna take forever.

I think the best use case for EVs are small motorcycles, scooters, and E bikes where they can be manufactured much more cheaply and use a much smaller battery. That way the economics of replacing the battery isn't a big deall. Just a few hundred bucks every 5 years or so to put a fresh battery in it. Something like a Honda Grom but electric and with 60 miles of range would be genuinely pretty awesome, for the right price and user serviceability... Then you sort of need a normal ICE car when you want to go on a bigger trip.

text: I had a 2016 Leaf with a 30kwh battery. One of the best cars I ever had. It was on a 3 year PCP deal, and only reason I didn't keep it was due to a change in jobs, the range was "very" borderline what I needed... literally only like 5-10 miles short, and 3 years after buying it 62kwh cars were then available (although out my price range). Gone back to petrol for now, but I'd be happy to go back to full EV sometime in the future. In 3 years of owning mine, I never ran out of charge... although I was bloody close a few times! Once I even managed to get it into "turtle mode". But the car's sat nav is fantastic and will give you routes via charging stations if it needs it. Using sat nav doesn't use any additional battery as the radio/sat nav is essentially always on. The car's heater though drains the battery for fun! Great in winter as you can tell the car when you leave for work and it will activate 10 minutes before to blast it with warm air and defrost any ice off the windows for you!

text: People love to say that EV's are so simple, there's far less to go wrong. text:
I said several years ago that EV batteries would have massive drops in range as batteries degraded,  its just what happens to all batteries under recharge cycles, and people scoffed at me for saying it. I worry now it will actually be even worse than I thought, 

When these EV's start hitting 15-20 years old will we see enourmous drops in range?  will this leaf will hit a point when it's top range is sub 20 miles fully charged? That's madness.

Hundreds of thousands, if not millions of 2008 combustions car are still be going strong... A combustion engine gradually fails, many parts can be fixed fairly cheaply, and total engine failure is rare, far more are scrapped for Rust, or run until they simple cant pass an MOT any more. 

But ALL EV's suffer battery degradation, it's how batteries work,  they all evcentually will hit sub 50 mile ranges... in fact they will all eventually see sub 10 when fully charged, Batteries degrade pure and simple, its not a part suddenly fails, its literally a linear range decrease for every battery. 

It's likely an average 15 years usable lifespan, and that's not being pessimistic, solar batteries too are sold as having a useable 15 year lifespans. It's how batteries work.

At some point ALL EV's will be too expensive to repair...  every EV car! 10 year cars are already worth less than the replacement battery packs cost! SO the Inevitability is battery death and the scrapyard!

The expert here is describing using battery packs from newer crashed EV to keep decade old EV's running... to as he said 'stop them being worthless or obsolete' that says a lot to me, not 20 year old cars, 10 year old ones! And the fix is more than the cars value...

I've seen tests where some a poor 10 year old leaf had a 70% drops in range...  Its not looking good for EV lifespans really.

We had just moved house but my kids hadn't moved school yet so it was a 21 mile trip to the school. The Nissan Leaf didn't make it. text:
From someone who is programming Battery Management Systems for a living:
On a cheap EV, I would suspect a short development time for State Of Charge and State Of Health calculations. Getting this stuff right is not easy, so the computer repeatedly makes wrong guesses and (luckily) corrects itself after it has noticed that the previous guess was wrong.
Cell age affects a few important characteristics of the cells, making predictions very difficult.

text:
A few years ago I considered buying a Nissan Leaf so I did some math's to work out how long it'd take before it cost a buyer less than a Nissan Note.
Based on fuel/leccy costs back in 2012, and with a projected annual mileage of 12k, it would have taken 13 years for a Leaf to become more economical than a Note.

Only trouble is, of course, that it seems a Leaf would never have made it to 140K miles on the original battery and I would have had to replace the battery after about 5 years (at which point the Leaf would have been ¬£8k less economical than the Note).
And, a quick check reveals that a 2013 Note is now worth about ¬£500 more than a Leaf.

Ah well, in the end I decided to buy a BMW 540i and I don't regret it.

text:
This first Nissan leaf never had a range (real world) of 124 miles.
Tha was the old , not working, claim (nedcap) nissan made for this car in 2012-2013.
Tge battery was told to be 24KWH...But nissan was the only one advertising with bruto capacity. Netto usable was 20KWH. With very carefull driving with a brandnew one (2013) it was possible to get ca 1225 km, not miles, out of it, This 124 miles was only possible when driving not faster as 30 mph
Also the range left is not even close. It just calculates how much miles (km) are possible based on the usage of the last 5 km.
After mentioning those above...
The car did not need maintenance (excepte one tyre change) in the 8 years I used it I got more than 1000 cycli on the battery in those years.
And as short range (I bought it for that) car it saved me tons of money compared to any comparable new bought ICE car the same size.)

author: @bobz1736

text:
People moaning about lack of range & range anxiety are idiots. All you need to do is calculate this simple formula before every journey:
Distance needed (A) x kinetic alignment to the power of -0.8 {6667.9} deduct 6% of the ambient temperature (allowing for fluctuation in battery temperature every 17 seconds.) Now calculate the gravitational load plus the tyre friction (will vary depending of weather conditions) & multiply the by 100% voltage (sinc) + air density to the power of 9. Then simply take this figure & divide by the distance you need to travel and that is your exact range but remember to re-check every 100 yards as there may be a fluctuation that compromises your figure.
Quite why you are all complaining about anxiety range is perplexing. You just don't know what you're doing, that's the problem.
author: @asensibleyoungman2978

text:
You had to know that starting off out of Economy mode you were never going to get the maximum city range of 120 miles in stop and go traffic and be automatically dropped to 100 or fewer miles of range even when the car was new.  If your stopped with your foot on the brake and not in park you are going to waste battery which is a given too.  One has to wonder if this was intentionally done for dramatic effect?

The expectation as it has been since new is that at around 18 miles remaining range indicated your going to get a low battery warning with the recommendation to stop and charge the battery then as you hit the last few available miles the expectation is to go into turtle mode restricting you to around 20ish mph until it shuts down.

If you are seeing less than 5 mile per kWh indicated on the dash (you might have to scroll through the options to display this) then the car has not be driven by a reasonable person and perhaps by someone who drove it like they stole it so the range estimate will be based on that history of poor driving.  Tire pressure and tires are also a critical item on a city car like the Leaf so if the original LLR tires were replaced with non-LLR tires and the tire pressures have gone low giving a more cushy ride then even when new range will drop quickly and you'll never get the max range from the vehicle.

Of course loading Leaf Spy Pro on your phone and connecting it to your Leaf with a Bluetooth OBDII dongle will tell you much of what the battery testing site will at a much lower cost and also allow you to log how its reacting during your trip.

Still for a city car designed for the less than 30 miles daily round trip driving of Joe and Jane Average the roughly 70 miles you get in Economy Mode from a 10 year old Leaf isn't a bad deal.  Driven reasonably they will get your through 2 days of driving and still charge completely overnight while your sleeping using the free courtesy charger that came with the car which requires no special wiring be done to plug it in.

That said I have a 10 year old Leaf and still do take 60 mile drives on some days.  Over the past 10 years I've only stopped once at a public charger and am still using the free L1 courtesy charger that came with the car and have not needed to install an L2.


Best!

An electric car loses 50% of its value in about 2 years, a petrol or diesel powered car loses about 30% of its value in the same time, and the latter is a lot cheaper to start with so you end up with a car that has a deteriorated battery and range and it is now worth about the same as a new diesel or petrol powered equivalent. I understand why the full electric industry is crumbling. 

I approve the electric car 100% but there needs to be a MASSIVE improvement in efficiency! Going from being able to drive 1000kms and then spending 5 minutes to do another 1000kms to only be able to do 400 (at best) and then having to spend 5 hours to do the same again is not one step back, it's a giant leap back. So until the fueling issue is addressed properly, i.e. either a hydrogen solution which can be implemented in all pre-existing service stations for a faster fill up and a longer range or a battery pack which can easily be charged in minutes, I don't think the electric industry will recover. 

And also if governments allowed renewable fossil fuels for older cars we wouldn't have to spend millions and cause tons and tons of CO2 pollution by scrapping old cars that could go on for years.

text:
None of this really makes sense. Used old Nissan leaf is the bottom of the barrel in terms of usability. 
But my issue is with how this is presented in terms of cost vs savings. 

The monthly cost of owning a used Tesla for instance, can be just ¬£200 or so, including fuel, which matches the cost of running say a 2003 volvo d5 at 35mpg 8000 miles a year. 
So the only difference in affordability is the need to finance, not the amount we spend per month to own it. 

I've never borrowed money to buy a car on finance, and I imagine many others haven't either, because the depreciation is jus lost money. So if you couldn't afford to buy it cash, perhaps you shouldn't buy it at all. BUT, the argument changes with EVs because they can save money every month in running costs (particularly when charged at home on a discount overnight tariff, but also in servicing and maintenance). And thus, cost you the same as some old banger to own over 5 years. 

So the question is, if you're going to spend the money to run the car anyway (which you are already), would you rather have an older ICE car that might still require random maintenance and unseen costs, servicing, Road tax, and fuel costs - OR would you prefer a newer modern car, with some luxuries, lower running costs and maintenance needs (than even a newer ICE car would), and still spending the same amount each month. 

I've always had old cars that i could buy outright. But with a used Tesla model 3 at ¬£14-15000, or a Model S at even ¬£13k, or a Hyundai Kona Electric (280 mile range) at ¬£10-11K, etc......if I just sold my diesel car, and put that money down as a deposit on finance and then paid ¬£200 a month. I could effectively have what feels like a brand new car with no additional coast to what I pay now. 

That's pretty hard to resist.  

Better yet, if all I did was drive to work and back in it, less than 30 miles a day. I could buy an old leaf, and then have our 2nd family car as the diesel long journey one. 
30 miles, 5 days a week for 44 weeks of the year is 7200 miles. Which would give a saving of ¬£1400 in fuel, not to mention the ¬£400 a year road tax I currently pay, ¬£150 service each year, and numerous little things that have gone wrong....that's ¬£2000 a year saved.

So as a second car just for a work commute it would pay for itself in 12 months.....doesn't sound stupid to me. 
In fact, the more I write, the more I have convinced myself to just go and get one. The time has come.

text: Random mold spors, is another feature unique to electric cars in a climate like Britain. Whos going to have the heater or aircon on, drying out the condensation? That residual humidity combined with the warmth of the sunshine converts the interior into a fantastic propagator for germination of seeds (and spores) Eventually you could be driving around (fortunately not for long each day) in a biological hazardous enclosed environment. In cold weather you'd have to make sure it was warmed up whilst still plugged in to your charger. And in warmer weather you'd definitely have to take the hit on the aerodynamics by driving with the windows down for ventilation. If you keep the car under cover then best to crack the windos down a bit to maintain airflow.

author: @nobby91010

text:
EMF radiation is a low form of energy released by any piece of technology with a plug or a battery that uses an electric current to function. Modern science has proven that extended exposure to these emissions cause adverse health effects.ELF radiation emits at a lower frequency than RF radiation, but both can cause biological effects in humans and the environment.

The closer you are to the transmitter or battery in an electronic device, the more you are exposed to this radiation, and the more at risk you are of developing adverse health effects.
WINDSCALE FUKUSHIMA DENIERS

text:
The key is research. You have to be educated on what you are buying.
I have a Leaf after doing my due diligence. It's not along range vehicle. Especially the older ones. I saw how how the batteries degraded quickly. The one I purchased had the lizard battery and at 34,000 miles was in reasonable condition. 
After 8 years of ownership the battery is degraded 25%. I can still get 50 miles out of it on a good day. It's something I knew when I bought it. It's great for local and some distance driving. Yes there is some inconvenience to it but I can tolerate it. The guess-o-meter isn't accurate. 
If your not up for the adventure, don't.

text: I have the earliest Nissan Leaf (2011) and the vehicle has been great for my particular use case of short trips only (ride motorcycle for long trips). In the 13 years of ownership so far I've spent about $1500 in total maintenance. The car's range at present is around 60-70 miles depending on how you drive it.  I've babied the battery (garaged, never leave it fully charge for more than a few hours, usually leave it around 50-80% SOC).  The only serious expense that cost me was last year replacing the coolant pump for the electric motor ($1100).  Other than that I've replaced the accessory battery 3 times, key fob battery 4 times, and one flat tire).  Best buy for me when I got it then getting a free home charger and $12.5k in subsidies off the list price.
author: @madmotorcyclist

text:
I really enjoyed this video, if my Mom had a place to plug in she would have been quite happy with a car like this (although she would have wanted it in red!). For me it would be useless, and a new Leaf not much better as I have a 100 mile commute.

But! The Tesla Model 3 I bought new in December works VERY nicely. I plug it in every night and have around 250 miles of real world range on a full charge, even driving over 70MPH on the highway. Last month I took it on a 2,000 mile road trip from North Carolina to Florida and in a couple of months I'm taking it on a 5,000 mile road trip to Arizona. 

Gas cars are great, and I've got a Jeep XJ I've had for 27 years and am not giving up, but after living with an EV for a few months I'm sold on them.

text:
Hmmm... 2013 Leaf 25k new. Now does 60 miles in one session max and will cost ¬£8k to improve the mileage. Its done 44k miles and is worth ¬£1500 as it is next to useless. 
On the other hand you could have purchased a 2013 Focus ST for ¬£22k - had a much nice car - driven 100k miles and sold for ¬£6.5k - it will still drive as nearly far as when new and be nearly as fast, maybe it will do another 100k miles.

¬£3k saving on initial purchase - ¬£5k extra value upon sale of vehicle = ¬£8k in your pocket which is enough to do 44,000 miles during that time period. Leaf milage covered.
 
With the Leaf due yet to cover its manufacturing carbon footprint as it is already due to be scrapped assuming its using coal-generated electricity: we can calculate the total CO2 emissions from charging the Nissan Leaf 

34.6 kgCO2/charge * 642 charges = 22,207.2 kgCO2 = 22.2 metric tons of CO2 

The 2013 Ford Focus ST emits about 183g of CO2 per km123. If it has covered 44,000 miles, it would have emitted about 13 metric tons of CO2 from driving. however it is proven to live on much longer, with the miles being covered by the initial saving and residual value. I cannot see how the leaf was particularly green or saving the owner much cash.

text:
I'm not sure this Leaf is representative for the age and mileage re. battery degradation for a UK car .  Just to offer some alternative stats. my car is a 24kW, is the same year and has covered 100k miles but has 82% of battery capacity remaining, 86 miles is the best range I've seen on the dash although I think low 70s is more realistic.  Leaf spy suggests its had 115 fast charges and 7000 slower ones.  
PS My car is tatty but was considerably cheaper that ¬£1500
author: @paulbradbury4612

text:
Ev battery‚Äôs have definitely gotten better by looking at this video, we have the Maxus delivery 9 ev‚Äôs in our fleet at work and some of them have already done the amount this Nissan has done and there‚Äôs no sign of battery degradation as of yet. The manufacturer specified they do 220 miles, but even when new they shown 178 miles with a full battery, and to be fair it is accurate, even when fully loaded weighing 4.2T. The reliability isn‚Äôt too bad, we have had a few that had problems where they wouldn‚Äôt accept a fast charge and had to be looked at but other than that they‚Äôre good.

I think the biggest issue with EVs are the fact the public fast chargers are ridiculously expensive compared to the fuel alternative, to fully charge the van at a fast charger it costs around ¬£100, so that‚Äôs ¬£100 for 178 miles compared to a diesel that would travel 300+ miles with the same amount. Then you have the limited ev charger‚Äôs themselves, if we‚Äôre lucky enough to find a space on a charge point, you‚Äôre guaranteed to have people show up knocking on your window asking how long you‚Äôre going to be, the other day I went to a charge station I known to always have free spaces to turn up and see them all full with 3 evs queued at the side waiting to get in, all 10 spaces full.

text: I possess a Peugeot 107 Allure, which is 11 years old, and I'm its second owner since new. It has a complete service history and has traveled approximately 65,000 miles. Over its lifetime, it has consistently demonstrated exceptional reliability, maintaining peak performance at 100%. With a single tank of fuel, it can cover a distance of about 300-320 miles, depending on driving conditions. Recently, I sought an appraisal from one of your competitors, and they offered ¬£1000 for it. In my view, this valuation renders it a superior choice to your vehicle, as it eliminates any concerns regarding range. Moreover, the electric windows in my car operate more efficiently than yours, and I enjoy the convenience of air conditioning, which I can utilize comfortably during hot weather without fretting about reaching my destination. Furthermore, the road tax for my car is free, akin to an electric vehicle. Therefore, I am inclined to retain my 107.

text: The main problem with the Leaf is that Renault omitted any tech to condition and protect the battery. This not only results in lower range when new, but it also results in drastically reduced lifespan/increased wear under a wide range of otherwise normal driving conditions. They put out a software update that results in at least more accurate readings as the battery degrades, but it does nothing to reduce the damage the battery incurs due to the lack of conditioning.

text:
Generally, used EVs are a bargain compared to if you buy one brand new; most of them, they depreciate horrendously and so quickly it's hard to really understand why you'd get one brand new outside of just flexing it to others. I know the car's value depreciate, that's just life, but it's so extreme with electric cars.

Last month, I saw a listing for a Mazda MX-30, which was only five months old with 1,008 miles, priced at ¬£15,500, which was under HALF its original price, roughly around ¬£32,000! I can also see another one, not the same spec or mileage (but not that high at 2,400 miles) but similar age for ¬£15,000. And an electric Corsa I see at a year old has lost over half its value already too. 

At these heavily tumbled prices, if they were brand new, which they more or less are, honestly, a lot more of us would be all over these electric cars if they weren't so overpriced to begin with; it doesn't suit me however, due where the car is parked in relation to the house, being on a curved portion of the street with the road seperating them. So the charging cable could get damaged by other cars going over it and trip people over who are walking by.

text: The range meter is working correctly, if irritatingly. It checks your instantaneous power use then assumes you will use the same power until the battery is empty. text:
Getting away from the obsessiveness that creates the ICE and EV tribes there are some obvious conclusions:

- EVs are too expensive to buy. 
- If you do long journeys EVs aren‚Äôt worth considering 
- If you do short journeys and a home charger a used EV will work well
- EVs are not as well made or as well engineered as ICE cars
- Suspension and body control on early EVs will shock you. Generally they are dreadful. 
- New EVs focus on connectivity, gimmicks and acceleration because the underlying engineering is ancient and it shows

text:
The biggest problem with electric vehicles (especially second hand ones) is that there's a MASSIVE elephant in the room. The battery.
Battery packs decline in performance and capacity and after about 6-8 years many are at the stage where they need maintenance or replacing. And the cost of such is prohibitive. Which renders the car completely worthless.
Nobody is going to buy a car that's needing a battery pack replacement or overhaul that costs ¬£13,000 or more.

text: Normal lead acid battery 'testers' are pretty useless and those batteries are very simple with 6 x 2.2 volt cells in series.  However with a EV battery up to 7000 torch battery size cells are connected in parallel  and those groups connected in series , with 14,000 individual connections it is simply not possible to monitor each cell properly. Those battery condition apps are telling fairy tales..

text: A big tax shock is coming for EV drivers,  up till now that have paid no tax and in fact have been subsidised and given huge tax breaks.... Public chargers now charge 20% VAT and already it is becoming uneconomical to charge an EV at public chargers,  bear in mind that ICE pay 60% + tax and fuel duty, and also pay VED.   From 2025 EV will pay a token VED ( don't want to scare the sheep just yet ).  Since 2018  every charger installed by government subsidy scheme has had to have the ability to remotely cut off charging to protect grid, and also to measure power used so that tax can be levied.   There is a big shock in store for EVangelists as the government brings in EV only road pricing, proper road tax, and proper taxes on electricity when charging an EV.  They have to make up loss of ICE revenue, and they will...

text: I drive my old diesel chugger around with the 'Miles remaining in tank' feature on most of the time, i.e., exactly the same as range in an EV. Of course the number goes up and down all the time depending on speed/gears/load etc. No one has to drive around AT the speed limit - it is what it says, the top speed anyone should be driving at. Driving at 50 in a 60 limit might infuriate some other drivers who haven't yet understood that, eg, 60 is the very most anyone should be driving at, and speed should always be part of driving to road/weather/other traffic conditions. So, drive at 50 in a 60, maybe 45 in a 50, although 25 in a 30 can be frustrating (funny how many people don't seem able to drive at a steady speed anyway), and the newer 20 limit should really be done at 20, despite the white van driving up yer chuff! My range starts at about 850 with a brimmed tank. So I only see '30 miles remaining in tank' infrequently, then 5 minutes in a fuel station et voila! another 850 miles of stress-free driving. Volvo V70 D5, 17 years old, only 160K on the clock, will last double that, goes like s--t off a shovel.

text:
So much cope in this video ü§£
Look, if you are someone with a privately owned residence, have access to home charging and do very limited miles then yes I see the point. Limiting someone to 60 miles range, well really 50-55 as nobody will run to literal empty before charging, is still fairly poor. Because that means if you need to travel more than 25 miles away from your home you WILL need to stop and use a public charger. Wintery day it will be slightly less again. I just find that completely unacceptable considering you can get about 33-39mpg from a 1.6 petrol (around that ¬£1500 mark) which is about 366-432 miles to empty on 50l. Even take 30 miles off that, nobody runs til you run out, you are still at worst 336 miles from full. My old 06' 1.9TDI PD Golf got 42-46mpg driving around suburbs (33-35mpg from cold and very short journeys), overall you'll get 450-500 miles to a tank.

I'm not hating on EVs, they suit very low mileage and people who have access to home charging. Whereas the internal combustion engine has a huge range of applications to suit the needs of the driver. Will technology improve? Of course, nobody is denying that improvements are being made. I fully believe in Hydrogen is the way forward for convenience and range, but again it has a long way to go. 

My final issue (not really relevant to this video) is new car prices are simply unattainable for the average working class family. Nearly every car manufacture is "going upmarket" and filling cars with ludicrous amounts of tech. Example, 10 years ago a baseline Skoda Fabia 1.2 petrol had an OTR of ¬£9995. Today, a 2024 baseline Fabia stands at ¬£19730, that a 97% increase in the OTR price. When you look at the BoE inflation calculator (very basic and there are discrepancies), the Fabia should be in the region of ¬£13200, a 32% increase with inflation. Dacia to their credit are still offering a baseline Sandro at ¬£13750, which don't get me wrong is still a 63% increase in the OTR price of 2014 at ¬£8395. For the EV market to thrive, you need a bunch family hatchback size models at sub-14/15k prices to hit the market TODAY. Making it more accessible for lower to middle income earners that will eventually sell on at the 3/5 year mark which makes even more people able to access EVs. None of this bullshit of Peugeot E-308s having a baseline OTR price of ¬£40,000, or VW ID3s with ¬£36000 OTR pricing, just locking more people out of EV ownership.
author: @alistaircampbell2129

text:
I bought a 2017 30 KWh model in the "Tekna" spec (Leather heated seat and steering wheel, 360 cameras etc) last year with 144,000km on the odo, and as a second car it's a fabulous option. This model looks like it's been abused. with an extra 80,000km on my clock, there's no issues with mine. I've only ever had to use public chargers twice since the end of May 2023.

One thing that people don't take into consideration is that the faster you travel, the more you go through your charge, kinda like the difference between using your phone screen and not. An advertised 124 mile range I would presume is Urban driving where these cars excel. And EVERYTHING uses battery - AC, radio etc. During the summer I feel confident using it for the daily commute on 2 days (50km round trip) but in the winter I charge it every night due to the extra power used with the AC, as well as the way batteries are less efficient cold.

text:
This would make sense as a second car for going to the shops etc, but not as an only car, this isn't enough range even for a cheap run around. No one will want to run it absolutely flat like this, so you are probably drawing a 15-20 mile radius around your house and that is your limit.

Newer EV car batteries are better and bigger, but at the 10 years mark will have done more miles and charge cycles than a car that only did 80 ish miles to start with. So this is probably pretty representative of what you will get. I expect this is why some of them are depreciating rapidly. There won't be many EVs over 10 years old and still on the road, so they don't have that base residual value.

text:
The whole EV idea is so fundamentally flawed. Broken secondhand market, insurance cost because of the dangers of battery fires/explosions, the general danger of damaged batteries in car parks and/or accidents, the impact to independent garages, the accessibility of cars to low income households if they were ever to become mainstream, the list goes on and on.

Bio fuels are surely a better solution, the same infrastructure can be used, everything else remains the same, less damage to the roads without heavy EVs. 

EVs are not the solution.

author: @dgattenb

text: What's different between a banger petrol car and a degraded battery EV is that the EV drives exactly as it did when new. Same power, same silent and serene drive, and reliable. All that happens is that the 'fuel tank' gets smaller over time. But with home charging you always wake up with a full tank anyway. And if that range is enough for a normal day's travel - happy days. An older petrol car becomes a money pit of repairs as the engine and its 1000's of moving parts wear out. And unreliable, meaning that often you cant rely on getting to work that day. Old EVs still fit in with many peoples plans. And when the tin bits eventually fail the battery is still a valuable item for people to sellotape to their wall at home and use as home battery storage for their solar roof. Contrary to the FUD merchant rants they are also recyclable when they ultimately fail, and the various expensive elements recovered to be used again.

text:
EVs are a scam. They depreciate insanely quickly. The batteries are not serviceable. Replacement batteries are as expensive as the vehicle. The process of building EVs is as destructive or more so than regular cars.  They're horrid in cold climates. 

Hybrid vehicles and research into renewable cleaner ICE fuels should be the focus. 

The biggest polluters (heavy industry and air travel) should be the focus. Nuclear power should be our main focus to power our homes. 

EVs are not the solution and are a scam. Its a disposable thing no different than an old cell phone. Planned obsolescence crap.

And the only reason you made this video is so you can condition people to buy these garbage cars from Car wow. üôÑ

text:
The NEDC driving cycle was rather flawed for range estimates, having a Zoe which was rated for over 100 miles taught me this the hard way. The interesting thing with the leaf is that the 24kWh model was rated at a ~75 mile range in the American EPA Tests which are more accurate.

Newer EVs past 2017 are done on the WLTP/WLTC ratings instead which are better, but still not quite as good as the american EPA ratings.

text:
My 1994 Nissan Navara ute cost me 1500 quid, has a range of 600 km, costs 75 pounds per full tank of Diesel, and is capable of hauling a heavy load on the back or towing a trailer.
Because it's 30 years old and has done 250,000 km, it has exceeded the Nissan Leaf's life by 3 times. So that means 3 heavy environmental impact EV's would have been manufactured to keep up with my 1994 ute.
When my 1994 ute is finally scrapped, only the plastic and rubber components will cause landfill pollution, compared to a greater percentage of plastics and the non-recyclable battery full of nasty chemicals that the Leaf sports (currently EV batteries are sitting in a storage waste pile in New Zealand since nobody here has recycling technology).
I only need to think about refilling my Diesel ute once a month, compared to the Leaf which would be daily or every second trip. Imagine the convenience of being able to forget about refilling your vehicle for a month.

text:
I have a Peugeot Ion (iMiev in disguise), which beat the Leaf to market by a few weeks.

In EV terms it's vintage: tiny battery that's now done 90,000 miles, fully charged every time as it spent it's life doing a 45 mile round trip in rural Wales.

Even now it does 40 miles a charge, which is three days commute, or a commute, a shopping trip and a trip to my parents.

To put on charge takes 9 seconds, to close my gates takes 12.  A charge is free in the summer (solar) and ¬£1.50 in Winter.

60,000 service (its first one) was 0.6 litres of ATF for the final drive.  Coolant change due at ... 20 years old (!).

Much more fun than you'd expect.

Outlander Phev for longer journeys.

Fits my use to a tee.

text:
If you live in an apartment, steer clear of these cars. 
With no ability to charge from your "home", you will be stuck using public charging. 
The cost is by the minute where I live ( Austin,Texas ) and would have been equal to paying 6 -7 times what I would pay if it were a gallon of gas. 
MUCH more for people in other countries where gas ( petrol ) is more expensive . 
Besides the huge cost to charge, it seems 6 out of 10 chargers will be broken, and the rest will be in use, or blocked by ICE vehicles. 
Also, you will have the added stress of having everyone mad at you for taking so long to charge your car. 
And what are going to do while it charges ? Just sit there and read a book for over an hour in the hot sun ? 
And you will have to do this almost daily if you drive anywhere near 20 miles per day.
( since there is always the ROUND TRIP there and back you have to think about ! )

My neighbor had a Leaf, and she would ( NO JOKE ...) hang a cord out her second story window and have it running across the driveway and over the sidewalk. 
Several people nearly tripped, and she would wake to find that her cord had been pulled out. 
Apartments also don't allow it because it is a fire hazard. 
She wasn't here long. 
I was thinking about a Leaf when they were $4,000 before Covid. 
Now, it is hard to find a bare bones, tired one for under double that. 
I'm glad I passed on the idea.

text: It‚Äôs very frustrating watching you try to build jeopardy about range without understanding how the car works. You shouldn‚Äôt use the guessometer. Turn on the battery percentage remaining display. That‚Äôs the true measure of the battery, not the range number. Because the range number is based on last driving style. Only drive this car in ECO from the start and without AC on. It‚Äôs a 10 year old car. You claimed it was a 2013 but you clearly have a 2011/2012 model with the old style inverter under the bonnet and charger in the back? This video sets a bad example of the classic Nissan Leaf which is one of the best value EV‚Äôs on the market. Please do your homework before posting about these excellent cars. It‚Äôs disrespectful to owners who know how to use them to their full potential.

text:
i saw an article recently where the government was blaming rowan atkinson for the slump in ev sales. they said in the article that the majority of people who buy an ev, switch back to a petrol or diesel for their next car. i know 2 people who have electric cars, the only reason is because theyre company cars provided to them and youd be stupid not to take a brand new car given to you.

personally electric cars do not interest me, ive sat in one and yeah acceleration is fast but i didnt feel anything for it. a couple years ago i got into what would be my mk2 ford focus st for a test drive. the 5 pot sound, feeling part of the car as you change gears and the torque steer made that car feel alive. an electric car out accelerates it by a mile but that old focus is my yard stick for a fun car. (yeah the fiesta st is good but the noise never did it for me)

as ive experienced more and more cars ive noticed newer cars dont feel as nice as older cars to drive. i owned a mk3 focus st and by the end i hated that car. the steering while accelerating was all over the place, i had people ask me "why does it move around when you accelerate?" and i said "the steering has no feel on centre". they didnt believe me until they drove it, even after about 10-15mins driving they werent able to stop it moving around under acceleration in a straight line. it was great in the corners but it annoyed me soo much that i couldnt ever use the straightline performance of the car.

Hello. So, what I want to do with this message is to simply show what the Gospel is. I am not trying to force my belief down people's throats. It's your choice whether you want to accept it. Please read the whole text.

So, a question: Do you think you are a good person? If so, have you ever stolen anything, lied, looked lustfully, watched adult material? All of those are sins and anyone who sinned is not good(on God's standard). You, I and most( most because babies don't sin, and maybe specifically mentally Ill people) purely human beings have violated God's moral law. Since God is just, He can't let sin go just like that.

The reason why blood must be spilled for forgiveness of sins is because the life of the flesh is in the blood, in the Old Testament Jews sacrificed animals for sins but the sacrifice of animals were enough to temporarily cover some sins. (it did not allow forgiveness of sins, unlike Jesus's, it only temporarily covered them). Jesus is the Lamb of God, the ultimate sacrifice for sins which is enough for all sins that have been done, are done and will be done. Jesus was buried and rose again. His resurrection proved that His death was enough to pay our penalty, the penalty for our sins. Jesus paid our penalty and in order to accept the free gift of salvation from God, we must trust in Jesus's spilled Blood, His finished work on the Cross for our Salvation. And then your sins will be forgiven because of what Christ did, you will be saved. text:
It's kind of pathetic really. A Ford Model T that's over a hundred years old has only lost about 10% of its' range.

I'm not so sure I agree with Matt on them being a good value for used cars either compared to internal combustion ones. I think for the most part it's about even. Assuming two of similar size and price are for sale, think of the pros and cons. 

The electric car does have less moving parts to worry about where the engine/motor is concerned, no cooling system to worry about, and, in most areas, will cost less to power than internal combustion vehicle of similar size.

The internal combustion car will have most of its' original range for longer trips, actually cost less to power in areas with high electricity prices, and weight is a big factor. The lighter weight of the internal combustion car means less stress on the tires, drivetrain, and suspension parts, all of which will last longer and thus, over time, cost less to replace.

They should be about equal in other areas like if your engine blows/battery pack dies, it costs about the same to replace, and crash damage would also be about the same. Thanks to new studies, we're also finding out that environmental impact is actually closer too, as while electric cars don't have the tailpipe emissions of internal combustion cars, they do have more pollution in terms of construction, disposal, and residuals like wearing rubber from tires.

As to safety, that's about even too. Teslas are super safe not because of their electric powertrain but because of how they're built. Tesla could build an internal combustion version and still be super safe. In addition, as we've seen from many videos, a bad wreck can still cause a fire just like in an internal combustion one.

text: I owned a Tekna Leaf for 9 years and was still getting 75 miles on a charge in the winter, which increased to around 90 miles in the winter. 90% of our journeys were in the Leaf and for holidays we used the Discovery. Now that EV's do more miles on a charge, I have sold both cars and bought an ID5 and can't believe the amount of miles I am doing on one charge. So far it has been 270 miles in the winter with a 100% charge and feeling optimistic for the summer. In fact I have been following VW's advice and charging it up to 80% which is equating to 240 miles.

text: Once EV owners realize that batteries are actually part of the cars long-term maintenance and "wear out" even when the car is sitting with limited use and then understand what the related costs are, many will be thinking that EV's in general are a rip off.   Sure, some battery chemistries last longer than others but they will all have reduced capacity and will be dead after a number of years.   The average USA vehicle age as of NADA reports in 2023 showed 12.5 years - well within the period for significant battery decline of all chemistry types.

text: EV with short range? No problem! Just put a diesel generator in the boot. The RAC have vans that will come to you and use a diesel generator to top up your EV. EVs are ok for city and short trips, but I wouldn't want one for a trip from London to Cornwall for example. But I work from home and can't have a home charger, while I mostly use my car for long trips, usually with a bicycle on the towbar. Good luck doing that with an EV and hoping to find a charger in rural Wales. I also dont want to baby sit my EV for 30 mins while charging at services, as I cant leave my bike on the towbar unattended .

The best use case scenario I've seen for used EV with battery depreciation is as gifts for your children as their first car.  

#1 These things are heavy and offer more protection from many impact angles.  Low center of gravity means they ain't flipping.

#3 You can track their energy usage closer.

text: Worth pointing out that this car is probably the worst case scenario. It has a small battery so it's probably been fast charged a lot. It has no temperature management so the battery gets hot when fast charging which degrades the battery and because it's so small it's probably been at 100% charge ver often which is even worse for the battery.

text:
~10 years old, 45k miles and only useful for a school run or a short commute. 
Remember that wasn't on predominantly faster roads, in rain or overly cold either so it will be worse as those factors are added. 
On top of that its got mould in it so welcome to a load of respiratory issues if you use it much and it still needs insurance, somewhere to park it and all the rest like any other car. 
There are plug-in hybrids with better range so its hard to see a use case for this thing unless you really want a car but never drive much more than about 30 miles and don't mind paying all the running costs for something with a similar usability to a golf cart. 
By contrast a cheap ice may well be in similar condition and have similar mileage but it will work as a car which can go where you like when you like. 
Even the old line about it being cheap to run is nonsense because it can't do enough mileage to make enough difference in fuel costs compared to an ice to even pay for its own insurance.

text:
Very informative, I've always wondered about long term value and future proofing battery chemistry in electric vehicles. If I buy today, and they put out a newer safer and more energy dense type of battery, would I be stuck with some early adopter FOMO or could I upgrade as needed. Sounds like, for the leaf at least, there was some real opportunity to extend the life of the battery and possibly upgrade the range. I wonder if that's the case for all EV's.


Saw a video of an Ionic where the owner had to replace the battery, and it was as much as the whole car cost to replace the battery! Hope they sort all that before I buy into EV's.

text: Secondhand EVs are even MORE of a concern than your usual Petrol/Diesel car! You still have your mechanical worries like brakes, CVs, driveshafts, wheel bearings, wheels n tyres etc Then you also have even more electrical issues. But the much, MUCH bigger worry of a ruined battery and a ruined battery will pretty much write the car off! This car is super low mileage for its age (I'd guess previous owners were old farts?) But the battery on this is clearly knackered! 50 miles on a full charge is shite! So a car like this will only be worth it if you NEVER do any long journeys and just use it to pootle into town here n there and can have the car on charge on your drive constantly. If you don't have a driveway and can't park near your house then these are utter SHITE and that's without kids and drunks pulling the charging lead out for a laugh! Plus you can guarantee that as soon as the majority make the switch to crappy EVs then the government will whack up the tax on electricity and dramatically increase EV road tax prices. There is no way on Earth that our government will just give up all that money they presently make on Petrol and Diesel tax when people change over to EVs and they will then start mullering EV drivers on anything they possibly can!

text:
to the guys who are anti EV after seeing this video:
1. this car and all other japanese, european are bad at producing EV. Only tesla and chinese manufacturers know how to build cheap and good EVs.
2. This was 1st mass produced car, which had bad technology from the start (chademo, no cooling/heating battery, bad chemistry)
3. Today, chinese car shows that you can achieve 350-800 km, super fast charges on one charge, and very low degradation
4. CATL biggest battery manufacturer says that their battery will be cheaper (around 3k usd, not 7k like now) and they are now selling batteries for busses with 1-1,5 mln kilometres without degradation. 
So we need to remember that japanese/european offer is quite bad, overpriced tech. 
Plus this is 10 years old car. The good thing there are niche caompanies giving second life to these cars, on is putting bigger used battery (there is a video where guy put the biggest 62 and has around 400+km of range and is driving on highway) the second companies are doing custom batteries with cooling/heating technology around batteries, giving them better condition and range)

Plus I'm really shocked with the price 1500 gbp? In Poland one of moto-youtubers are selling his family car nissan, with maybe slighlty better battery condition for around 7k gbp.
So for 1500 gbp you can get ev + you can pay 10k euro for changing the battery for bigger one in Netherland and for around 15k you might have EV doing 350-420 km on one charge. 
New cars with similiar range costs 30-40k gbp. Hmm. Just wondering is it worth.

text:
I'll consider an EV, purely as a commuter car someday only when:
1) I am financially comfortable enough to own separate cars for commuting and playing (family road trips, camping, etc)
2) There is a sufficiently mature, robust system in place for safe recycling of their batteries at no cost to the consumer
3) And most importantly, when the electricity we use to charge them is not ALSO generated from the exact same fossil fuels we're allegedly trying to become less dependent on

Oh, and if that day ever happens, I assure you it will not be a Nissan Leaf. Seriously that is one of the ugliest cars made in the last decade, electric or otherwise

6:30.  I would expect the early Nissan Leaf (with the cream interior) to be a future 'collectors' car (along with the 60 Ah i3 and the first Tesla Model S85).  Get the battery cells swapped out and the range fixed and it won't be long before you are taking it to car shows on sunny summer weekends.
author: @FFVoyager

text: If it was real 60 miles, it wouldn't be so bad, but it's not really. You can't drive around until you break down, so you need to leave yourself a 20% margin. That means a range <48 miles. If you do plan on trying to stop charging at 80% to preserve what is left of the battery, that's an effective range of around 35 miles, probably less in winter or if we had a heatwave. My regular commute is 32 miles. I used to have high hopes of getting a used electric car as my next car, but it seems like a scary proposition in that context. Maybe the one after that, if the current models with the 200-300 range still retain 100+ usable range in a few years, it will be viable.
